My expectations were quite high, and at the end of a first impression... I wasn't quite taken away with it as everyone else would seem to be. It had such extremes of light and dark, happy and sad, brutal rage and sweetness that it was almost too much for me to take, and I don't always mean in a great way. For a film with such strong actors and a control of the mis-en-scene, it's impression on me was that of an overbearing fable whose perks came mostly in the last third of the film with the big turning point of tragedy.But a second viewing helped things, and I no longer see it as being the "overrated" one, whatever that could ever mean with a director like Fellini. Indeed, it's without a doubt a classic... and, still, I consider this dark fable of the strong-man Zampano taking the feeble smile/frown Gelsomina away from her family to be his assistant while alternately terrified of him and in wonderment over the acrobat Il Matto "The Fool" my least favorite of Fellini's classics. I say this in not trying to say to any perusers of IMDb's comments section (whoever you are) to stay away. On the contrary, do watch the film, maybe even study it if you're that kind of movie-watcher. Even if I might be less inclined to eat a particular pineapple-chicken pizza from a master chef, it's still undeniable it's still some of the best pizza around. Same case here.Perhaps a small deterrent comes with the language barrier; Anthony Quinn and Richard Basehart are terrific here, but in watching the film you have to listen to the Italian version so as to hear everybody else's dialog, including the perpetually charming Massina. So unless one does hopscotch with the DVD remote to go back and forth between English and Italian, we don't quite get the full force of the performances. And yet, a repeat viewing reveals things I hadn't noticed before (as does happen with Fellini movies), little stitches of touches to scenes, little actions done by characters like Gelsomina or even the BIG performance of Quinns, amid the wide brush strokes Fellini takes to the characterizations.Or maybe it's as simple as its own simplicity for me: it's deceptively simple, and at times one has to wonder what is really going on between Zampano and Gelsomina, why she stays with him through all of his brutish outbursts, and why she doesn't stick with the kind-hearted and whimsical Fool. It's hard not to recommend La Strada, and I certainly do. It may even become greater in my mind the longer it sticks with me, or when it comes on television in further years. For now, I only can say how it didn't affect me as deeply or with the same knock-me-on-my-celluloid-futon like a dose of Mastroianni in 8 1/2 did or even, dare I say, Massina in Cabiria.

Speaking as a novelist, it's incredibly difficult to write a book. Numerous parameters have to be satisfied: plot, dialogue, character development, premise, believability, relatability, continuity, etc. And they all have to balance with each other. To accomplish all these things with the medium of film must be ten times more difficult, so my hat is off to one of the greatest directors in film history. Fellini delicately pushes and pulls, shaping, twisting, lingering on shots here and there, wringing alternately joyful or sorrowful moments out of nothing. If you think that films are just entertainment, La Strada will prove you wrong, there is real life buried inside this film, it's more of an experience than just a film; how in the world Fellini crafted relatable characters is a marvel in technique.I've watched this film three times in my life, and each time I got more out of it. There are three scenes that have really stuck with me over the years: the first one was when they visited the convent, and the nun takes an interest in learning all about Gelsomina, she's clearly fascinated with this traveling waif who shows up at their door, and even invites her to stay. But Gelsomina makes the decision to stay with Zampano. This is significant because clearly she feels like she belongs with him, even though he treats her badly. The second scene is when the fool convinces her that Zampano likes her; her face changes considerably, and when she picks him up from jail, she looks like a brand new woman, full of hope for something better. The third scene is the end, where Anthony Quinn pulls out every horrible thing that Zampano has ever done and lets it wash over him the way the waves wash over the beach, and we see a lifetime of regret play over his marvelous features. I wonder how many takes it took to get that scene, and it's all done in a single shot.I'll watch this film again maybe in another ten years and I'm sure I'll see something new again at that time. This film is like an old friend.

A mis-matched relationship triggered by the passing of cash to fulfil an economic necessity: he, Zampano, (Anthony Quinn at his gruff, brutish best) is a sideshow strongman playing to passers-by in the street, she (Giulieta Masina, reminiscent of both Chaplin and Stan Laurel) is a childlike urchin, possibly mildly retarded, whose dislike of her new owner is slowly eroded, not by a change in his attitude, but of her perspective of the world and her place in it. It's a change brought about by the Fool, a tightrope walker and Zampano's nemesis. That the tale of these three will end in tragedy is inevitable - the way in which it occurs is not so predictable. Like a miner doggedly prospecting for gold, Fellini patiently uncovers the humanity in a thug who appears to have none, and while Zampano might not find redemption, he does belatedly acquire a devastating understanding of just what he has allowed to slip through his fingers. A powerful, heart-wrenching masterpiece.

Every once in a while I come across a movie that's highly regarded by "everyone". This is one such film. To be frank, I don't understand all the hype around it. There are many much better movies than this.First off, how could Gelsomina's family just sell her off - and to a brute like Zampanò! Strangely, Gelsomina offers no resistance. What's worst: this brute treats her horribly and yet she has the hots for him and even wants to marry him - and she refuses any chance to stay away from that gorilla! This woman can't be in her right mind to proceed that way....Zampanò is the typical gorilla: he is a street rioter, intimidating, powerful, violent, brutish, drunk, entertains crowds by breaking an iron chain bound tightly across his chest. I liked the character "Il Matto - The Fool". He was quite fun, although he was a little crazy sometimes because he busted in laughter for anything, even if his laughters were hilarious. And it was hilarious when he threw a balt full of water on Zampanò.Aside Gelsomina's impossible to understand crush on that gorilla, there are some other things I didn't understand. When Zampanò beat the hell out of "Il Matto", he just died after? He died from 2 or 3 beatings? Where did Zampanò hide his body? And when Zampanò pushed the car off the road, it just caught fire? It caught fire for being pushed off the road? Anthony Quinn is great as Zampanò and Giulietta Masina is great as Gelsomina, but best of all was Richard Basehart as "Il Matto".Then again, to understand all this positive feedback on this movie is beyond my comprehension but at least Bob Dylan must have liked it. He cites 'La Strada' as an influence for the famous The Byrds's classic song "Mr. Tambourine Man". At least he took something good from this.

reviews.review_title: The firs ever winner of the Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film.
reviews.content: It always had been quite hard to give great foreign language movies always the recognition and attention they deserved. For this reason they introduced the Best Foreign Language Film category at the Academy Awards and this movie shows perfectly why. It was a more than worthy first winner within the newly created category, that of course also still exists today.Thing this movie manages well is that it's quite an heavy handed drama but yet is more perfectly accessible and even somewhat entertaining to watch. This actually helps to enhance the movie its more dramatic moments and serious themes and you don't really have to be a more regular and hardened foreign film watcher to really like and appreciate this movie.It's a simplistic movie with its settings but it's still a complicated and multi-layered movie with its story and characters. The characters and their relationships with each other aren't standard or predictable in any way. It's a real beautiful story, in all of its ugliness, that never goes over-the-top but at all times remains a realistically feeling one.But it's not just the story that makes this movie a great and interesting one. It foremost is also still the way it got told by its director and cast members. Federico Fellini was a real special director in terms of his visual and character approaches but above all he was also a real great storyteller.It's such a beautiful looking black & white movie, that manages to capture the perfect atmosphere for its story. Desolated, sad and dirty but still very heartfelt and warm. Also Nino Rota's musical score really goes along great with the film and enhances this atmosphere.Giulietta Masina is truly perfectly cast in her role. She plays a character that really doesn't has an awful lot of lines and she has to act a lot more with her body and facial expressions. And her whole psychic and face were just perfect for that. She plays an innocent and somewhat naive character, who brings the most warmth to the movie. Anthony Quinn is the brute, in one of his Italian movie roles. Quite funny though how he is supposed to be a strong man and does his act with his shirt off but I just can't detect a muscle on him at all. But oh well, it makes it apparent that he got cast more of his acting skills, rather than his muscle power and physics. Now days that often is the other way around, it seems.A more than worthy first winner of the Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film.9/10http://bobafett1138.blogspot.com/

reviews.review_title: A great, enduring work of art.
reviews.content: This is one of those elemental works that expresses a truth about humanity with a power that goes straight to the heart. The story brings together a brute, a clown and a fool, and each follows his or her nature so that the outcome is inevitable. The nature of the brute is to destroy; that of the fool is to mock; that of the clown is to be simple. This triangle plays itself out in our everyday lives, hounding us relentlessly, breaking our hearts and, from time to time and in place to place, our spirit. You don't have to look far to find it.Here that triangle is powerfully incarnated by Anthony Quinn, Richard Basehart, and, most memorably of all, in the beautiful, amazing, unique, unparallelled Giulietta Masina.As the years go by it's become more difficult for me to watch this magnificent movie. Why? Well, it would be comforting to think that people have learned something from the cruelties meted out by our brutish selves on our simplicity, but we know perfectly well that little or nothing has changed. Nothing probably will. La Strada shows us exactly what will happen, but it happens anyway. I find Maestro Fellini's depiction of it more and more upsetting. Heaven help the clowns.

reviews.review_title: The Power of Spirit Overcomes Brute Force
reviews.content: 'La strada / The Road' could be interpreted as a religious story about ransom, but it does not fulfill the charge of being unrealistic. The film opens up a social prospect on the joint experience between two people on which every society is based on. The story arises from the personal reality of director Fellini, his memories and percepts which showed him the journey of two creatures who are unsolubly connected with each other without knowing why.Showman, juggler and muscleman Zampanò (Quinn) meets the family of Gelsomina (Masina) and sells 10,000 Lire for taking the blonde girl with him on his motorcycle, modified as a mobile home. From now on, they are traveling together through the Italian province - he performs his big-wig on meager market-places and Gelsomina must assist him dressed as a clown, drumming and collecting the money from the audience. It is a strange couple: the small, childish-naive, young woman, in love with life, who is looking forward for her new job and the coarse, grumpy man who was toughened by the hard life on the streets, who is blind for the environment and who mechanically reels off his performances. Always the same sayings to the same climax when Zampanò blows a chain by tensing his chest. Gelsomina, on the contrary, rolls her eyes like a clown while carrying the hat slantingly on her hat, the mere sight of a trumpet bewitches her. When she wildly beats the drum for the first time, she soon feels a struck on her naked legs. Zampanò does not tolerate jokes. He drills Gelsomina until she works and behaves like he wants her to. Zampanò is a slogger who understands his physical skills as mean to subsist. Entirely different is the tightrope walker Matto (Baseheart), who comes across with Zampanò and Gelsomina several times on the road. For Matto the artistry is a light-hearted game, the art is his life. His performance aloft in the air are brim-full of wit, facility and something supernatural - in the manege he wears angel wings on his back. That is why he and Zampanò are obviously arch enemies.'La strada' is not only a poetic parable on society in the form of a road movie, above all it is a sad love story where you can discover wonderfully magic moments, powerful and ironic, sad and quiet, this film has an unique rhythm: the immediate change between frisky and silent scenes, between day- and night-scenes. Catholic symbolism traverse the whole film: the angelic Gelsomina finds herself often in the role of a religious figure and in one scene she stands in front of a poster which advertises the "Blessed Virgin". Matto personates a Christ-like figure who tells Gelsomina an allegory. You can also see all three characters as a personisation of the Holy Trinity: Zampanò is the "Body", Matto the "Spirit" and Gelsomina the "Soul".As a lyric tale about loneliness, the film also aims at transcendency. Not the surface of the things is relevant, but its penetration: Fellini wants to perceive a deeper meaning which makes life, despite every hardship, more liveable. "You won't believe it, everything is useful", Matto tells Gelsomina while she - being abased by Zamapanò - doubts her own self and questions her existence on this Earth. Even every stone that lies on the floor. Matto picks up a stone. "For if its useless, everything is useless. So are the stars." She nods. Understands. And she smiles.

Though 8 1/2 is generally regarded as his masterpiece, Fellini's La Strada is truly a remarkable and surreal, neo-romantic masterpiece in its own unique way. The potential of the film is hard to articulate at first look-for their is no introduction to what the characters world. In a way, it is a surreal. In another way, it is romantic. But overall it collides with every element and boundary to this category. The cinematography, the acting, the direction and scripted material is executed well. Thiscould only come from the darkest chambers of Fellini's soul-and the most beautiful. I recommend it without a doubt.

Bernard Herrmann wrote some magnificent musical scores -- "Citizen Kane," "Vertigo" -- but the music was incidental. It corresponded to and commented on the events we see on screen. Nino Rota was responsible for the scores of "La Dolce Vita" and "La Strada". You could whistle his tunes. He never wanted to escape his country's operatic traditions or his own family background -- circus clowns. His score here is among his most memorable.Anthony Quinn is Zampano, an itinerant strong man who breaks a chain with his chest. That's his entire act. He breaks a chain with his "pectoral muscles." He doesn't make much money. He hits one rural village after another and finds an occasional wedding party, after which he passes around the hat. But he needs a cheap assistant to play drum roles and travel with him, so he buys Gelsomina, Giulietta Masina, from her mother for 10,000 lira. She's not beautiful and she's a little batty and no one is sorry to see her take off in Quinn's vehicle, a motorcycle drawing a small covered cart, which one character aptly describes as "a piece of junk." I'll make the story short. Quinn is so coarse and brutal he can clear rooms without using a gun. He mistreats Masina, womanizes in front of her, slaps her around, gets drunk and scolds her, and thinks only of himself. Here's how they spend their first night together. "Get up there," orders the lustful Quinn. "Tomorrow," says the frightened Masina. "Ahh, get IN!," snarls Quinn -- and he picks her up and throws her into the back of the cart. For some reason Masina sticks with him voluntarily. Richard Basehart is The Fool, a skilled tightrope walker who befriends and advises her, while tormenting the the odiferous, ill-nurtured lewdster. Catching The Fool alone, Quinn beats him and accidentally kills him, which drives Masina over the edge and leads Quinn to desert her on a snowy mountain road. Years later, he hears that she died insane. Quinn winds up drunk and alone, weeping abjectly on a night-time beach.The three principals give performances that could hardly be improved upon. Unfortunately, Quinn's Italian had to be dubbed and they chose someone with one of those harsh gravelly voices of the kind you once heard in cheap sword and sandal epics from the 50s. Quinn's own voice was deep and mellow, though he could turn it bestial at will. As for the character he plays, The Fool describes him as one of those dogs who looks as if he want to speak but can only bark. Basehart has never been better. He's animated, silly, provocative, sensitive, and thoughtful. After being beaten, Fellini has him stagger a bit, remark that his watch has stopped, and then die by degrees. That watch has stopped forever.Giulietta Masina more or less carries the movie. It's her story. And she fits the role like an enzyme fits its substrate, every groove of the role being accommodated by her performance. She has the clownish face and manner of a child, with huge, heavy-lidded eyes, and features that are extremely expressive without any overacting.It's black and white; it has sub-titles; the locations are grimy. The production designer accomplishes the oddball feat of turning a real street square into a desolate stage set, with wind skittering the litter along the pavement. And if you see the movie, you're not likely to forget it soon.

Armed with the Oscar he had won for Viva Zapata Anthony Quinn took off for Italy where he finally got a starring role for Federico Fellini in La Strada. Quinn was not the prettiest face in Hollywood and it would take something extraordinary to bring him up from the ranks of good character players and make him a star.The animal magnetism that his roles had shown were finally given an international stage to shine in La Strada. Tony Quinn is nothing short of magnificent as the brutish strongman Zamprano whose very inarticulateness speaks volumes about his character. The man's just looking for a little love, like we all are.Quinn purchases young Giulietta Masina from her family in ravaged post war Italy to be a kind of helper and stooge in his itinerant strong man act. If this were the United Kingdom, Quinn as a street entertainer would be called a busker. Eventually the two of them hook up with a traveling circus that has a most talented high wire act in Richard Basehart, another American expatriate.Basehart is a harlequin type character and he gets to both Masina and Quinn in different ways. She responds to his elfin charm, but for some reason he pushes Quinn's buttons. It results in tragedy for the two of them.La Strada does not end in a manner that would have fit the omnipresent Code. More I can't say, but it could have been why Fellini's film was not seen in the USA for three years since its initial release.When it did get here La Strada won an Academy Award for Best Foreign Language film. Another sign that the Code was crumbling.As much a star as Quinn, Basehart and Masina who incidentally was Mrs. Federico Fellini is the cinematography of post war Italy. The devastation of the Italian campaign is everywhere, even 10 years after Rome was liberated. La Strada got another Oscar nomination for Best original screenplay, but the cinematography should have merited consideration.The theme from La Strada actually has words though they're not sung. The song was featured on an album done by Perry Como a dozen or so years after the film came out. La Strada still holds up very well after more than 50 years. And it is certainly a milestone in the career of Anthony Quinn and a must for his strong legion of fans.

My Rating : 7/10La Strada literally means The Road or The Way in Italian. This is a road movie. And some say it's one of the first road movies made.It's a good movie too, by the way. A brutish man named Zampano buys the innocent urchin-like Gelsomina to be his traveling companion in his one-man carnival act. That's the main premise of this film. Zampano is physically and emotionally cruel to Gelsomina and yet Gelsomina is supportive of him and her child-like perception make her a perfect complement to the selfish, oafish character of Zampano.A simple structure, reminding of the Italian neorealism seen in movies like Bicycle Thieves or Umberto D albeit with a bit more grandiose feel due to Fellini's direction style.7/10 for me.

People might see symbolism in the characters of this film based on the elements. Director Federico Fellini certainly includes his familiar tropes such as the sea, circus, clowns, beach, good women and prostitutes.To me this is a road picture of two not very bright people who end up together. Zampano (Anthony Quinn) is a circus strong man travelling around in a beat up camper van pulled by a motor cycle.His companion Rosa has died, he goes to tell the news to her mother and buys Rosa's younger sister as a replacement. Gelsomina (Giulietta Masina) who he brutally trains to be his assistant.Zampano is a brutish thug, a drinker, a womaniser. I was never convinced whether he loved or cared for Gelsomina, I believe she cared for him and even loved him.When both join a larger circus she comes into contact with the Fool (Richard Basehart) who is a clown and a high wire act.He is sweet to Gelsomina, even a kindred spirit but he senses that Gelsomina loves Zampano and maybe he loves her but cannot show it or say it because he just lacks the intelligence. The Fool like a few other people throughout the film offers her a way out from Zampano but she refuses.The Fool also has a deep dislike for Zampano, always taunting him and driving him to a rage. Eventually their path will cross again leaving Gelsomina mad and Zampano to abandon her. At the end Zampano is left unfolding his emotions to the sea. Maybe he eventually realised the love he has lost.There is distinctive music from Nina Rota. Actress Masina has a clown like way of movement which looked like Harpo Marx combined with Charlie Chaplin.You can see why the circus wanted her to stay. She had an inane sweetness in contrast with Quinn's Zampano whose only ability was the strongman act where he could break chains with his pectoral muscles. If he had any sense he might had realised that that being taunted by The Fool could had been incorporated into the circus act with beneficial results.There is a tragic undercurrent in this film very much from the first scene heightened by the black and white photography and Fellini's symbolism's which he revisited many times in the course of his career.

I've always loved Fellini for his vision and music, but never been particularly moved by his films, but this is an exception for me. The strength of Quinn, the almost desperate need for love of Massina, and the camera all combine to make this a masterpiece, even though he clearly had no money to think of. What he does, how he creates an emotion and lets us absorb it, is the work of a genius.One of the best films ever, I think .

Federico Fellini made his mark on the world with "La strada" and won Best Foreign Language Film for it. He sets the movie in the impoverished environs of postwar Italy. Giulietta Masina plays Gelsomina, whose family is too poor to take care of her anymore. They sell her to Zampano (Anthony Quinn), a strongman whose act is breaking chains with his chest. Zampano ignores Gelsomina to the point where she hooks up with a man who calls himself The Fool (Richard Basehart). When Zampano tries to take revenge on The Fool, everything ends tragically.Of course, "La strada" is not just about the main plot. It's about humanity in general, and how world events affected the Italian people. The two male stars are both Americans, but speak Italian perfectly. Not just that, it's a perfect movie.

This Fellini film is an unforgettable experience. I have recently seen two high-level "neo-realist" films: Vittorio De Sica's "ladri di Biciclete" and Luis Bunuel's "los Olvidados". After seeing them, I thought it was almost impossible to see some "neo-realist" film superior to these two. But this "la strada" can still be up one level in relation to the films I mentioned. Giuletta Masina is simply amazing in her role of Gelsomina and Anthony Quinn is brilliant as Zampano. It's a cruel movie, being sensitive. It's a sensitive movie, being cruel. It's a movie like no other, of those who will be with us forever.

reviews.review_title: Fellini delivers a bit differently here, bit he delivers nonetheless
reviews.content: "La Strada", which means "The Road", but the title is never really translated into English when it is shown somewhere, is an Italian black-and-white movie from 1954, so this one had its 65th anniversary last year, which also means it was really high time for me to see it. It runs for under 110 minutes and is of course directed by Federico Fellini, who is also one of three writers contributing on the screenplay here of course. The film is of course entirely in the Italian language, but looking at the cast you would not necessarily expect that. Sure, there is Giulietta Masina at the center of it, but there is also Mexican Anthony Quinn (just won his first Oscar back then) and American Richard Basehart. The latter I was really thrilled to see because I remember him well from his Columbo villain performance that he gave much later in his life/career and it could not have been any more different compared to his turn here. But we shall get to that latter. Masina was really Fellini's go-to actress and it is a bit sad how despite that she is nowhere near Mastroianni's level of popularity still nowadays. So this movie we have here is probably Fellini's most famous that does not include Marcello. This had to do with Masina's strong performance (even more impressive because she had really not much dialogue, especially compared to the two babbling men), but also with the fact that this film won Best Foreign Language Film and it was the first of many triumphs for Italy (and Fellini) and Fellini backed up the win one year after immediately with another Masina movie. We talked about that one on another occasion already though, so let's focus on this one here now instead.It is about a young woman who has to leave her poor family and she is literally sold to a circus strongman for the woman to have some money again, because there are many mouths that need to be fed. This was basically the introduction. Most of what follows afterwards in the first half is the woman's interactions with her gruff master and you can never really be sure if he (Quinn) is fond of her or not, also from a romantic perspective as Basehart's character indicates later on. Early on, he definitely is not. There is the example of how Quinn's character has other women while travelling with Masina's, even if he always returns to her apparently. What was even more telling though was the introduction sequence really when we see how Masina's character is a joyful young woman, but when he is through with telling her how to introduce him to the crowd, she does it the way he wants, but she also has tears on her face. She herself plays a clown during these performances and this should not be seen as disrespectful or anything or sad (I know there is a lot of talk about clowns being sad), but she seems to have a fun time most of the time. Anyway, back to her love-hate relationship with Zampanò (I wonder whe the accent is where it is as it seemed to me as if "Zam" was the dominant part when pronounced): She has moments when she hates him, like when he violently attacks her and pulls her back, which makes her a bit of a prisoner even, but also we find out that sometimes she likes the theory that the gruff man is just not capable of showing his real feelings towards her, but they are there. I am sure feminists today would not appreciate this at all. As for Quinn, he plays one of the most virile masculine characters I have seen in a while and that chain breaking part, which is shown many times, sure adds to that as well. I still find it incredible difficult to like him. The ending maybe shows that he saw nothing special in her all along. At least not when he leaves her back, even if he gives her the trumpet and may have a slight guilty conscience. But if he had feelings I think he would have stayed with her, regardless of what happened with The Fool (Basehart) before that, maybe at the end though he questions his decisions when he breaks down in tear. In any case, The Fool is right in saying he himself will not live for long, while the strongman will have a long life ahead of him. You can of course question if it is a happy life or if The Fool's short, but joyful life was more worth it. That balancing/dinner scene up there was surely entertaining how he delivered to the crowd, something Zampanò to this degree could only have dreamt of, even if admittedly he is not unsuccessful either.With that I mean of course with that is the moment the prankster is killed. Now these two keep having a special relationship with the pranks from one side and the aggression from the other, but that surely was unexpected. It wasn't even intentional by Zampanò, but still. His reaction also shows that he is not really angry at what he did or felt sympathy for the man, but he is just scared of being caught by the police. And all that after he just stole a lot from a monastery or something despite the nuns being so nice towards him (and Masina's character too). Still, he is not a cold-blooded murderer or psychopath or so, just somebody who does not have control over his aggressions. The way he unleashed against The Fool was even more harmless than I thought he would honestly. far more harmless really. The Fool himself thought he could die perhaps and the moment he reached for that tool was really the only moment when The Fool was really serious you could say. Shows you the significance of the situation. Now I talked a lot about the two men, but as I move closer to the end of my review, I want to make a few other references too about this film, especially one about Masina's character. We may see the brute as an antagonist the way how he acts towards her and because looking at how much she is mesmerized by The Fool, he is a bit of a haven for her, but let us not forget that this is the man who leaves her behind too, who says her face does not look like the face of a woman, but rather like an artichoke. I mean what was up with that. The guy is probably very childish and clearly immature and does not see at all what impact words can have. I am not even talking about the romance aspect and how much you can hurt somebody who has feelings for you, but this is also nothing to say to a friend at all, especially a female friend. So both men have major deficits in interhuman communication and weren't the right ones for her, even if she might disagree. That should be enough about the characters now, just one general statement from me still that I felt this was sometimes not typical Fellini honestly, especially how story-wise this was really a film destined for making a major musical impact as it is frequently the case in many of his other works. But it did not really. Luckily, it delivers in many other fields instead and I certainly enjoyed the watch. Comedy is also typical Fellini, not too much, not too obvious, but here and there a moment that will make you smile. For me (and many others in the audience) the highlight was really seeing how Zampanò deals with ice cream, also towards the end already during the epilogue section. Okay, that would be all then. Unless you hate old (Italian) black-and-white movies, this one definitely deserves to be seen and I was glad I watched this for the first time ever on the big screen on the occasion of a Fellini retrospective dedicated to the man's 100th birthday.

Having watched this movie three times, at first release in a cinema, later on TV, and this week in another cinema in the same building where I saw it all those years ago, I am still trying to come to terms with my own reaction to it. I have some difficulty recalling the details from the 'fifties, and I wonder if this is because I am in denial. Is the movie so bad that I threw it from my mind? This retired cinematographer is appalled at the camera work. It is badly lit, and the continuity is a joke. Perhaps the movie is so different to the Hollywood product of the time that people like me welcomed the contrast. La Strada makes many of the same errors as the Hollywood westerns of the 'thirties. Shots from the motorcycle look like they were done with the mechanical horse Hollywood used pre-war.Then, there are all the awards. Were the other movies of that year so bad that La Strada stood out? The episodes along the road certainly seemed to herald the 'road' movies that followed.The age of the leading lady? Was that really the voice of a naive slow learner, or the voice of Fellini's wife, obviously an experienced stage performer? I was reminded of the mature Norma Shearer trying to be the sub-teen Juliet in Hollywood's Shakespearian opus. Let's not make too much of Fellini's post-synch sound. It was just plain dreadful.

reviews.review_title: A Classic from Fellini and Anthony Quinn
reviews.content: Anthony Quinn (Zampano) strolls through the streets of Italy with his motor and runs a one-man show where he breaks a chain by expanding his chest. He hires a poor girl (Giulietta Masina) from her mother to work as an assistant.Zampano is a rude emotionless vagabond. On the contrary, Giulietta plays an emotional but talentless girl who is desperately waiting to hear some words of love from Zampano. Zampano's neverending aggression and the girl's frequent breakdowns carries the film in a gloomy atmosphere. The film is beautifully directed by Fellini and the story is enriched by their encounters with interesting people.

It is a cliche that 'La Strada' is Fellini's most Chaplinesque film, not just in the excess of sentimentality or the heroine's mugging, but in the film's very structure, which, like 'Modern Times' and so many others, is rooted in the circle: people circling around Gelsomina as she leaves; the circus; the narrative as a series of sketches, beginning, ending, beginning again; the return, over and over, to the beach.But this is in many ways an anti-Chaplin film, the circle and the road leading not to renewal, continuity or hope, but inertia and death. 
This is a film that should not work - the central figure, part-Little Tramp, part-Holy Fool, is mawkishly unconvincing; the film's misogynistic morality is slightly dubious - and yet it is frequently magnificent, full of the grotesquerie and hysteria that is not supposed to be in the pre-'La Dolce Vita' films; the rough style is heartstoppingly reminiscent of the nouvelle vague; the harrowing neo-realism is laced with surrealism and epiphany. Best sequence?  Either the wedding, or Richard Baseheart on a tightrope.

reviews.review_title: The life of two performers on the road
reviews.content: La Strada, or The Road if you prefer, tells about young woman named Gelsomina (Giulietta Masina), who gets taken in by a travelling strongman performer named Zampanó (Anthony Quinn). Well, to be more accurate, she gets sold to him by her family. The movie follows them along as they travel the countryside, gathering money by doing various shows, the most prevalent being Zampanó busting a chain tied around his chest by flexing his muscles. You know... high art.The movie has its ups and downs. The characters themselves are easily the best part. The two main characters meet all kinds of people along their journey, including some other circus performers, the most interesting being The Fool, played by Richard Basehart. But it's the two of them that hold the central focus for the majority of the runtime and they are quite fascinating. Zampanó, a gruff dog beaten by the world and ready to beat it back, yet not an evil man per se. And Gelsomina, a sad and lonely child trapped in the body of an adult. What makes them even more interesting is that they don't really change all that much throughout the film. Sure Gelsomina moves from depression to having some form of affection towards Zampanó, but yet she still remains exactly the same character she was in the beginning. Likewise with him. It's simply that we get pulled deeper and deeper into them as the movie progresses. They don't change, we simply learn more about them.As far as the story goes, it's not overly complicated, which is fine at first, but in the end leaves you wanting a bit more. It's a character study movie, certainly, but in the end all they do is wander around and have arguments with one another. I liked it, but these two great characters could have told a bigger story without any problems.Still, it's a nice movie to check out and a really strong early work from director Federico Fellini.

Sometimes a character or image from a film is so engrained in popular culture that even non-cinephiles would be familiar with them: Charlie Chaplin's Tramp from any number of his films, Marilyn Monroe in "The Seven Year Itch", Marlon Brando sitting in an office with the blinds drawn and a kitten in his lap from "The Godfather"... There is an image from this film of our hero Gelsomina (Giulietta Masina, "The Nights of Cabiria") done up in clown makeup, and I remember knowing that image far before I ever saw this film, or even knew what the image was from. For whatever reason I watched a few other Fellini films before ever getting around to this one. I must admit, while I did love this movie, I wont claim it to be better than Fellini's masterpieces, "La Dolce Vita" and "8 1/2", but it's certainly a great film.
For our full review of La Strada and hundreds of other reviews, articles, and podcast episodes visit us at True Myth Media!

reviews.review_title: A slowly unfolding tragedy that both tender and taxing.
reviews.content: Life is a cruel and punishing road that often seems indignant at our audacity for simply walking along it. There are no guaranteed stops but for that ultimate destination, and so how we get there is entirely up to us. Or sometimes not at all. This isn't Cormac McCarthy's vision of The Road of life, in which the entire landscape is enveloped in nihilistic despair, but what McCarthy's road and Fellini's road both share is that the people traversing it have been dealt a meagre hand in life and have to work with what they've been given. The father and son in The Road, despite the post-apocalyptic oblivion that surrounds them, can survive because they have that sacrosanct shield of familial love to protect them. Here, the seed of love between the girl and her master was un-watered, unacknowledged, the cards they were given were misused, often not because of lack of trying but because of a pure inability to grasp them. What Fellini has constructed, like McCarthy in The Road, is a world of which the logistics do not matter, as the greater environment, whether that be an apocalyptic theatre or a or the sparse Italian landscape, simply serves to highlight its characters and their tragedy at its core. I had described this film as conventional, but it is only conventional in the sense that doesn't have these characteristics, and it's not something that you're necessarily deciphering every image. What we have here is a road movie, both literally and metaphysically (yes? The metaphysical road? Yeah, you know what I'm talking' about) in which is immediately accessible because the emotion is so palpable. I was mentioned in my Drive review the weight of physical acting, and how that often bridges the divide between film and audience just as effectively as dialogue does, and that really applies here. Gelsomina, played by Giulietta Masina, Fellini's wife, is such a wondrous presence; her waifish frame, the round face that is like a fishbowl in which we see all manner of emotion flicker by, and the naïve way in which she clowns about, both tentative and joyed is such a sympathetic synthesis that I'm surprised as to how I hadn't actually discovered this character before watching this film, and it seems that is generally agreed that she is something of a female counterpart to Chaplin. She has one of those readily iconic faces, and when she dons her clown make-up she wears these sharp vertical eyebrows that seem to exaggerate her already widened eyes, and throughout the film it is easy to get lost in both the humour and the sadness of them.Gelsomina is part of a large rural family that lives by the seaside, and in the opening shot she frolics at the shore, surrounded by a gaggle of playful children. Life seems fairly simple, and then the rugged and imposing Zampanò (Anthony Quinn) turns up, and buy Gelsomina from her mother for 10,000. The whole film carries that neo-realist edge, a world of social struggle, as it seems Gelsomina's mother is financially burdened, as we learn that she has already sold a daughter, named Rosa, prior to this arrangement. Apparently Rosa died. We are never explicitly told how or why, but it is easy to speculate, as we see Zampanò who light up a cigarette, all hulking physicality, as he waits to carry of this young girl away from her family forever, and as we soon learn the full extent of his brutality. Zampanò is a man who only seems to be able to communicate through his harsh physicality, through which he lives his entire life. He is a street performer, who only has one small novelty act, in which he tightens a chain around his chest and breaks its grip by a powerful exhale. He lives by rote, a simple creature who can easily break physical barriers but isn't capable of breaking emotional ones. As the movie progresses, it seems to almost fluctuate between different rhythms, at some points a comedic routine as when Zampanò tries to teach Gelsomina how to perform her simple musical duties with a drum and trumpet, in which she approaches with innocent wonder, and other points the feeling is quite sparse, with long stretches of sadness. I suppose it reflects the metamorphosing of their relationship, growing but never settling because it never has the chance. Gelsomina is ultimately something of a cipher, she seems slow-witted, her eyes flit about with wonder, she takes delight in learning the simplest of things, yet when she speaks she has something of a wiser understanding about her, and I wonder if her clownish innocence isn't something more calculated, perhaps because it is only through this approach that she feels safe enough to interact with the world. But then maybe this is the tragedy of the characters, as they cannot quite reconcile their outward persona with something more sensitive inside; amorphous and flickering between two states. The Fool, who we later meet, played with wonderful exuberance and passion by Richard Baseheart, is the classic fool, who comically strides around at mocks people at his leisure, often cruelly, which is ultimately his downfall, but beneath that is a wisdom and understanding that he rarely shares. "I don't know for what this pebble is useful but it must be useful. For if it's useless, everything is useless. So are the stars!" He encourages Gelsomina to understand her own potential as a person, and is the one perceptive enough to recognise the bond between her and Zampanò. But Zampanò is the final tragedy, a brute with a love he could not begin to articulate or even recognise, and when he finally breaks down and cries on the beach, a place which seems like the end of the world, it hurts because like the other characters he understands when it is already too late, and now there is no more road left on which to travel.

Strada, La (1954) *** (out of 4) Federico Fellini's classic about a strongman (Anthony Quinn) who buys a rather strange girl (Giulietta Masina) and adds her to his circus show. This was my second Fellini film and while there's a lot to enjoy there's still something that didn't really connect with me. Fellini's visual style is certainly a treat on the eyes and I really loved the opening segments on the beach and when Quinn is buying the girl from her mother. The strongest aspect of the film are the performances by the two leads as well as Richard Basehart as "The Fool". Quinn is one of the greatest character actors of all time and he manages to be quite brutal here even without using his muscles. His facial expressions and the look in his eyes tell you everything you need to know about this character. Masina is very good as well but I wouldn't say she steals the film (something I've heard others say). The music score is also quite beautiful but in the end I really didn't connect with either of the characters and I felt the film dragged in spots.

reviews.review_title: "For if its useless, everything is useless. So are the stars!"
reviews.content: A whimsical and often magical story that is one of Fellini's more linear and accessible stories. Not only is the warm heart of the story apparent, but the visuals, in typical Fellini fashion, provide striking background imagery.Gelsomina (Giulietta Masina) travels with Zampanò (Anthony Quinn) to earn money. Together they journey and experience various people. Amazing performances especially from Masina coupled with an endearing score. Il Matto (The Fool) provided some laughable moments who meets his fate the last time he meets Zampanò. Simple yet striking screenplay with a sample lines: "For if its useless, everything is useless. So are the stars!" - The Fool. More of an emotional drama that have no direct or structured plot, which lets the viewer wait what happens to the leads. La Strada shows several metaphors such as the nuns (religion), The Fool (humor and realization that everything has a use), Zampanò (greed/selfish desires/loneliness/physically strong yet morally weak) and Gelsomina (a talent never given the spotlight/purity/innocence).

Gelsomina, a very peculiar young woman, is sold by her mother to an itinerant artist, the great Zampano, taking her on a painful and distressing journey. One of Fellini's most iconic films. It is a love story, in part, but mostly a story about broken dreams and values, and the meaning of life, seen differently by each characters. It is a caricature of a time of female submission and abuse, but also of emancipation from a spirit that wants to be free, and that tries to break down all barriers to achieve it, in a way that is sometimes surreal. The cinematography is sublime, with great individual shots, capturing emotions in an impressive way. The soundtrack is a key factor for the success of this work, composed by Nino Rota. I watched this in a movie theater recently, and wow, what an experience!

reviews.review_title: Delves deep into paths of human existence
reviews.content: "La Strada" is one of the films Fellini made in his neo-realistic period, and it's an absolute highlight at that. The picture depicts the complex relationship between Gelsomina, a naive girl, and Zampanò, a traveling entertainer, to whom she is sold by her own mother. When Gelsomina is just about to discover the wonders of the big wide world, she finds out that she's only used as a mere tool by her companion, but there's more to it than that. "La Strada" is a movie with a soul. It's a realistically portrayed, highly emotional journey, which constantly oscillates from Gelsomina's good-hearted innocence to her master's brute force, and in between there seems to be no compromise. To Zampanò the road just goes on and on, aimlessly, as if that's all there is to life, it's reduced to his own basic needs, and everyone else just fills out a replaceable role. There couldn't exist a stronger contrast to his strong masculine presence than Gelsomina and her innocuous self, smiling in the face of insults and persistent hardship, devoid of any prospects, but her joy lies in the very moment - or the next, as she easily forgets. The unlikely pair however in a way needs each other, even gives their lives meaning, though realization of this fact might happen too late...Plot, screen play, black/white photography, Nino Rota's score and the main cast of this touching human story are all top-notch. Anthony Quinn plays the stone-hearted Zampanò to the T and Giulietta Masina, Fellini's highly talented wife, makes a supremely memorable impression as the simple-minded, but endlessly endearing Gelsomina. "La Strada", which one might translate with "The Street", or maybe more poetically and philosophically inspired with "The Path". It's the road that the two characters walk, everyone for himself or both together, and by accompanying these characters the picture delves deep into human existence, holding the viewer tight in its grip. A prime example of film-making at its very best.

reviews.review_title: Tribute from an anarchist poet(me), to another(Fellini)
reviews.content: How can you write about The God of Cinema, than in the manner in which it is said that the Bible was written, that is inspired by God himself? But that Fellini was still earthly, like me, with a biography similar to mine plus physically resemblance(Mussollini was for him what Ceausescu was for me...) so, I'm having easy words come to mind from somewhere in the ether, the infinite, where perhaps he, Fellini, still creates characters, directs, writes, draws, takes everything for his films which he never realized as long he lived on Earth. Very seriously, what can you write about La Strada? What can you write about the faces of Anthony Quinn and Giulietta Masina? About what they can express only by their presence? What about the music of Nino Rota? What can you write about the work of Fellini, who was going through the deepest depression, after his only child just died in real life? You can not write anything, you just got to see the film, again and again, and feel yourself what Fellini wanted to communicate to the world. The fact that La Strada won an Oscar, for me, is zero. I appreciate what is beyond the film, the simple message about life and love. I will only quote Zampano: "If there's any delicate person in the audience, I would advise him to look away 'cause there could be blood." Much more than 10.

When I come to this IMDb site and read the comments, I feel I'm among friends. Anyone who adores "La Strada" is someone I have a bond with and would welcome into my house.To me, what makes "La Strada" special is that every man has something of Zampano in him and every woman contains some part of Gelsomina. As to Il Matto, he's the artist. He sees life from a unique perspective. Perhaps that's why he's doomed.But that makes the movie sound formulaic, which it is not. In fact, "La Strada" contains elements that puzzle me to this day. What's the deal with the horse and the sick kid? I figure it's Fellini's way of saying, "Life has mysteries."There are moments in this movie which are engraved on my mind forever. Gelsomina's pride at the first time she introduces Zampano's cheesy strongman act. The look on her face the first time Zampano slaps her.And Anthony Quinn's final scene on the beach. Has despair ever been shown better? It always chokes me up, and I'm a hardbitten 58-year-old newspaper reporter.RIP, Federico. I feel your bearhug on all humanity to this day.

This weird film contains unlikable and annoying characters and a tired old plot. I decided to watch this movie a second time, but this time I watched the original dubbed American version. It was interesting to hear Quinn's real voice in that version. This is what they do in foreign films with American actors for the U.S. release. They speak English, while everyone else speaks, in this case, Italian, but it looked like they recorded Quinn's voice originally, but they had to re-dub it over for the American release. It's Quinn's voice, but not synched well. However, hearing Quinn's real voice did add much more character to him, and boy, was his character a jerk. It was funny how Gelsomina sounds like Trixie from Speed Racer. I don't condone watching a movie dubbed, but in this case it paid off. My grade raised from a D to a C-. I enjoyed Basehart a lot more on the "Voyage to the Bottom of the Sea" TV series. Nice cinematography, composition and contrast, interesting images, such as the black horse and the three marching band solders, but that really is it.6.8 (C- MyGrade) = 7 IMDB

reviews.review_title: "You may not believe it, but everything in the world has a purpose."
reviews.content: I'm finding Federico Fellini, much like Japanese director Akira Kurosawa, to be something of an acquired taste. That's a politically correct way of saying that I don't care very much for their pictures. Maybe it has something to do with the era in which they worked. Both their styles seem to be drawn out and methodical in a way that doesn't engage this viewer. Personal taste I guess.I recently watched "The Nights of Cabiria", another Fellini film with his wife, Giulietta Masina in the lead role. I had to wonder about the way her character Gelsomina was written for this story. There seemed to be particular emphasis placed on the idea that she was ugly, or at least as fashionable as an artichoke, both descriptions offered by The Fool (Richard Basehart). Additionally, I couldn't tell at first if she was mentally challenged, because she did little to engage in a meaningful way with other characters. But later on, she seemed to be an intelligent person but with hurt feelings, and you could sense the dichotomy in her personality. Adding to the illusion, she was made up to look like Harpo Marx, with hints of Chaplin's Little Tramp in the way she conducted herself.For this viewer, this was Anthony Quinn's best role, though I haven't seen "Zorba the Greek" yet. I thought he did a good job with a complex character, even though his outward persona was pretty much a brute. I actually had to laugh a bit regarding his strongman gimmick. If you took notice, the chain he used for his act was secured with a rather tenuous link that didn't look like it would be too tough to separate. It wasn't as if, as Zampano claimed, that he was using his muscular chest to break an iron chain.I think this picture would have had more resonance for me in a modern day setting, and if the characters were a little better developed. I didn't really identify with the players in any meaningful way and the randomness of the situations seemed contrived in a way. I might do better with a second viewing, but with so many movies and so little time, it's going to take a while.

reviews.review_title: Enjoyed this one more than 81/2...An Amazing piece of work.
reviews.content: I usually have a lot to say about a film. My first time seeing La Strada however, struck a cord in me that when I saw it, I couldn't shake it. It's one of those films that you can't forget, no matter who you are.In it's own way, it's a simple love story about a hardcore Man who pays for a simple minded woman to join him on his road trips as he travels around entertaining people with his chain trick. Quinn's character is hard on the humbly woman, beating her when she doesn't perform to his expectations and criticizing her. One would question her desire to want to continue with him despite his poor treatment against her, and finally her heart submits to his crudeness and she falls in love with him anyway. However,in the hands of Fellini, it works perfectly, leading up to one of the most emotionally moving endings I had ever seen in movie history. Sure the ending was expected in some way, which didn't take away from it's power despite everything.La Strada is my favorite Fellini film. A must see for any film goer.

Gelsomina (Giulietta Masina) is told by her mother to go on the road with traveling strongman Zampanò (Anthony Quinn) after her sister Rosa had died. She is simple, naive and sweet. He teaches her to play instruments by beating her. She is great at clowning and the kids love her. However she can't take his cruelty and his womanizing. She runs away and sees another street artist Il Matto "The Fool" (Richard Basehart). Zampanò tracks her down and grabs her off the streets. They join a traveling circus which Il Matto is already performing at. Il Matto ridicules Zampanò at every turn. Eventually they fight, are both jailed, and fired from the circus.Giulietta Masina looks like a sad clown. She is so compelling. There is just something about her big eyes and sad face. Anthony Quinn is amazing as the brutal Zampanò. Their relationship is one of a battered spouse. There is a sadness and dread that starts from the first moment of their meeting. They have created two amazing memorable characters.

reviews.review_title: A most admirable small-scale exercise in staging a three-character choreography
reviews.content: Which is the Greatest Italian Movie? Some say Fellini's La Dolce Vita or 8 1/2. Some say Visconti's The Leopard. Others, Pasolini's Gospel. Rome, Open City? Cinema Paradiso? That's an amplification. Investigation of a Citizen Above Suspicion? Overemphasis. The Conformist? Baloney. (For me, by the way the worst is Brunello Rondi's Il Demonio). Fellini, however, hasn't always dated gracefully. La Strada is the one particular instance when he still proves his personal and unique touch to tell a rather ordinary story. It isn't an ego epic like "8 ½" or a moral mural like "La Dolce Vita", but a lovely work of Septième Art Forever. It is the story of Zampanò (Anthony Quinn), kinda road runner attached to Gelsomina (giulietta Masina), a girl with kinda mental retard, on their trips to shows his circus-like performances from town to town. Zampanò is hard and cruel to the only person who gives him everything. A masterpiece in every sense of the word including three of the best performances of all time - Quinn, Richard Basehart as Il Matto & Masina, - including Neorealist touches and immortal music composed by Nino Rota with full undertones of nostalgia,. Simply spectacular. An art jewel.

From director Federico Fellini (Nights of Cabiria, Juliet of the Spirits, Fellini - Satyricon, Amarcord), this Italian film featured in the book 1001 Movies You Must See Before Die, so I wasn't going to miss the chance to see it. Basically Gelsomina (Nights of Cabiria's BAFTA nominated Giulietta Masina, Fellini's wife) is forced into joining circus strongman Zampanò (Lawrence of Arabia's Anthony Quinn) on the road after her mother accepted 10,000 lire, her sister Rosa before she found out died in the same situation. The strongman makes a living performing for public crowds with his "unique" performance breaking iron chains with his chest and passing a hat for tips, with her naive nature she goes along with it. Gelsomina also learns how to play the trumpet and snare drum, some dancing, and even gets made up to be clown for the audience, but Zampanò only treats her with cruelty and torment despite her trying to please him. Finally she is fed up and decides to leave him, and going into town she watches another street performer, Il Matto - The Fool (Richard Basehart), who makes his living performing as a high wire artist and clowning, but her master finds her and forcibly takes her back. They see Il Matto again when the two of them join the travelling ragtag circus, and there Zampanò is constantly teased by the fellow performer, and it is after water is thrown on him that he draws a knife, and the both get arrested and fired. Gelsomina is trying to find a purpose in life now she is in her situation, but Il Matto is released and suggests she joins him, and that everything in the world, a pebble, even her, have a purpose, even if it is unknown. Zampanò, who brushed her off at the idea of getting married, catches up with them again, and he gets his revenge giving Il Matto many blows to the head which eventually kill him, and he hides the body and car. Gelsomina now has her spirit broken, becoming near lifeless for a few days, and the strongman fed up with it abandons her while she is sleeping. Years pass, Gelsomina finds comfort hearing a song she often sang herself, so supposedly she goes on for a better life, while in the end we see Zampanò getting drunk and wandering onto a beach to cry uncontrollably and break down. Also starring Aldo Silvani as Il Signor Giraffa, Marcella Rovere as La Vedova - The Widow and Livia Venturini as La Suorina - The Sister. Masina once again gives a lovable performance with her unusual facial expressions, and Quinn is also really good as the antagonistic and nasty strongman, I did get occasionally confused, but it is a simple story into the dark side of the performing world, and with its interesting imagery and historical content I can see how it can be considered an influential drama. It won the Oscar for Best Foreign Language Film, and it was nominated for Best Writing, Best Screenplay - Original, and it was nominated the BAFTA for Best Film from any Source. Very good!

reviews.review_title: The beginning of famous profile for Quinn
reviews.content: It was a permission for Quinn to be A mega star in Hollywood after his role (Zampano) in this movie to attract the tensions of Hollywood by his best scene at the end of this film that (Zampano) cried with tears of regret and loss that he did not pay attention on the love of his partner in acrobats after her marriage to leave himself foe the sea to tell for him his epic of misery and failure as a soul friend for him to treat him from sadness and tears.Fellini recorded his name in the global corner of cinema by his magic camera that helped people to imagine any scene by high artistic sense for generation after generation.

Gelsomina (Giulietta Masina) is a young woman who is sold to a traveling circus strongman Zampanò (Anthony Quinn) by her impoverished mother. Together Zampanò and Gelsomina tour the Italian countryside, perform on streets for small sums of money and develop an unusual relationship. He is a gruff and abusive man prone to binge drinking, while she's naïve, fragile and almost otherworldly in her endless optimism. Only after meeting a wild circus performer named The Fool (Richard Baseheart), the characters are forced to change for good in tragic ways.The black & white cinematography looks very beautiful, as does director Fellini's wife Giulietta Masina as Gelsomina. She plays the role with very exaggerated expressions but it only adds to her strange charisma, whereas Richard Baseheart's over-the-top antics as the fiddle-playing jokester come across as more annoying than amusing. In a way this makes his ultimate fate all the more meaningful to the theme of the film though. Is the theme submission? Oppression? Guilt is certainly one of the important emotions explored by the story, but the rest can be figured out by each audience member themselves.Even though I don't personally consider La strada Fellini's best film, it is a calm and beautiful experience all the same. Some technicalities like the obvious dubbing and subsequent bad lip-syncing hurt the impact a little, but they're only minor complaints in an otherwise well-created film. It's not for everyone, but those with patience and interest in meditative art films may find it very rewarding.

reviews.review_title: Lovely To Look At And Quite Entertaining, But A Little Dissspointed With The Ending
reviews.content:
Up until the death of The Fool, the movie was quite entertaining. Then I became unsettled, and disappointed. I couldn't figure out why at first, then I realized that I was anticipating a different sort of ending. I wasn't happy with the manner in which Gelsominas death was handled. But maybe a second viewing will make me feel differently.It's still quite good though, and that is why
I rate it as high as I do. Not good in the way we are told a film like Parasite is good when its actually crap. But good in the way Casablanca is good.Anthony Quinn is excellent in the role of the brutish Zampano, but it is the character of Gelsomina, played by Italian actress (and wife of Fellini) Guiletta Masina that drives the film. At first I wasn't sure what to make of her portrayal, with facial expressions that reminded me of Stan Laurel or Chaplin. Eventually though I fell in love with it.

While Giulietta Masina usually gets all the acclaim for her Chaplin-esque performance in "La Strada," it's Anthony Quinn's outstanding turn as the earthy, brutal Zampano who finds redemption at last that powers this film. I don't quite understand how these international productions come together, with everyone speaking different languages (How do they hold conversations if they don't know what the other person is saying?). The inevitable confusion certainly doesn't show up in the final film. "La Strada" is heartfelt, poignant and, for all its humor, surprisingly downbeat. Probably Fellini's best film, more engaging than his later self-indulgent fantasy romps ("Juliet of the Spirits," "8 1/2") that have become dated so quickly. "La Strada" has a timeless quality that transcends generations.

This is truly a great Classic 1954 masterpiece with fantastic acting by Anthony Quinn,(Zampano) and Guilietta Masina,(Gelsomina) who pour their heart and souls into their roles. Zampano was an entertainer, like Houdini, breaking out of chains and traveled around with a motorcycle hitched on to a wagon and traveled from small Italian towns throughout the countryside, in all kinds of weather. Zampano purchased Gelsomina from her mother who could not afford to keep her daughter at home any longer. Gelsomina plays a very simple minded young girl who starts to learn the hard way how to deal with her male companion. There is very deep and spiritual meanings portrayed throughout the film and it is a must see film.

I'm not the biggest fan of Federico Fellini; and that's putting it lightly. This probably won't reflect very well on my part; but I found 8 1/2 and La Dolce Vita to be two of the most extraordinarily boring films I've ever seen (hey, at least I'm honest). I am pleased to report, however, that La Strada is nothing like the previous two Fellini films that I've seen - and that's nothing if not a very good thing! This film follows a nice straight narrative, and Fellini never strays off the central path. The film, therefore, is easy to watch; and this in turn makes it easy to care for the characters and take in the various themes that the movie offers. It's nice to see the director not overdoing his film, and Fellini shows here that he's not a bad storyteller. The film follows Gelsomina; the daughter of a poor family, who is sold to a travelling fairground wrestler named Zampano. As the two travel together, a bond forms; but Zampano is mean to the young girl and it isn't long before she wants to escape him...even though he may love her. The film takes in themes of love, family and redemption, among others; and the way that Fellini implements these elements into his film is very skillful, and ensures that we can care for the characters and their fates. The ending of the movie is particularly beautiful, and it's hard not to feel for the characters, after watching their story unfold.

The more I become convinced that Fellini may be the greatest cinema director (certainly including Spielberg, another genius) ever.Yes, we can congratulate D.W. Griffith for his discovery of the close-up and so much more.Too many directors to name or appreciate. And it's only just past a century of them.But surely, Fellini must rank among the pantheon.I don't know if "La Strada" is his masterpiece.I would be hard-pressed to select merely ONE.Certainly, Fellini's output is richer than Orson Welles'.More varied and vivid than Frank Capra's.More visually stunning than John Ford's.Deeper than John Huston's.More provocative than Hitchcock's.Who else is left? But "La Strada" is inarguably one of the most magnificent films ever made.Who, but Fellini, would give those two "American" Hollywood actors -- Richard Basehart and Anthony Quinn (actually Mexican) -- the chance to display their acting chops? No one.Combine them with the brilliant Giulietta Masina and you have incomparable casting.And a foolproof script. And cinematography. And music.Fellini here, early in his career, makes everybody else -- from D.W. Griffith to Spielberg -- look like an amateur.He did so for another three decades.He still does. He's been dead for nearly two decades.No CGI here, or anywhere in Fellini's work. Not needed.Just a story, some actors and a camera.The best stories, actors and cinematography in history.Oh, yeah.And the best director.Take your pick of Fellini."La Strada" is perhaps the best place to start.It will break your heart.And teach you everything you ever wanted to know about film making.

No one wanted to finance this movie about a young girl sold to a traveling circus performer who ends up dying. I wonder why. It took the international success of I Vitelloni for Fellini to find the money. He cast his wife, Giulietta Masina, as Gelsomina, the simple girl sold to Zampano, played by Anthony Quinn, who worked concurrently on two productions at once (the other was Atilla) and Richard Basehart as the Fool. Taking advantage of the common Italian post-war practice of not capturing sound while filming, Quinn and Basehart were both allowed to speak in their original English but were dubbed over into Italian for the final film. La Strada represented a certain break from the neo-realist movement, but it is interesting to note that the dubbing was common in neo-realist films, which helped to break the reality of the action at a certain point since the dubbing was never perfect.So, Gelsomina is the eldest living daughter of a poor woman in a seaside community. Zampano shows up with news that Gelsomina's older sister, Rosa, died under his care, and he offers Gelsomina's mother 10,000 lira for Gelsomina to replace Rosa. The poor woman feels like she can't do anything but accept, offering up platitudes about how Zampano will teach Gelsomino a trade in order to assuage her own guilt. However, despite being essentially sold into a form a slavery, Gelsomina privately smiles at the whole series of events with a hat on her heard that she playfully bounces back and forth before anyone can see.Zampano is a cruel man, though. He rapes Gelsomino the first night they're alone. He whips her when she can't get his introduction as he wants. He abandons her in a small town for the night as he goes off to enjoy an evening with a local woman. He treats her poorly during their performances where he tries to put on a large show but is mostly centered around him breaking a chain with his chest, a feat that may be as dangerous as he says but feels very small especially when they join an actual circus later. Through it all, Gelsomina is a fragile creature. She searches for her happiness wherever she can find it like planting some tomatoes on the side of the road as Zampano recovers from a hangover or trying to entertain a small, bedridden child near a wedding that the two have tried to entertained but only got fed instead. She has this constant desire to do good, but Zampano tests that in her.It gets so bad at one point that Gelsomina simply runs away. She runs to another town where she sees The Fool tightrope walking between two buildings over the town square. Suspended in the air above the ground, he tries to eat a bowl of spaghetti, only to lose it, his chair, and his table to gravity, all while captivating Gelsomina in the square. Eventually, Zampano finds her again, takes her back, and they end up joining a circus where The Fool has also accepted a contract.Now, Fellini has said that the three characters represents Water (Gelsomina), Earth (Zampano), and Air (The Fool). Others have said that Gelsomina represented the soul, Zampano the body, and The Fool the mind. I feel like devolving the characters to representative elements, though, is a disservice to the characters themselves who feel like much more than just metaphors, and that really comes forward in the later parts of the film.Gelsomina has a chance to escape Zampano when he and The Fool get into a fight and both get fired from the circus. She could continue on with the circus, but The Fool tells her that everything and everyone has a purpose, even something as insignificant as a pebble. She takes this to mean that her purpose is to help Zampano become a better person, so she becomes determined to stay with him no matter what. She will be the light to him. Being post-war Italian, this doesn't really work out that well as Zampano and Gelsomina encounter the Fool on the road later where Zampano hits the Fool so his head hits the car behind him and he dies. Gelsomina's mind breaks at this act of violence, and she can hardly function anymore, stuck in the moment where she wept over the Fool's dying body, and constantly repeating that the Fool is hurt, leading to Zampano simply abandoning her.Years pass and Zampano continues his act, joining another small circus and performing his little feat for small crowds. In a small town, he hears the song he had taught Gelsomina and asks the woman singing it about it. She tells him of the girl who had shown up to the town years before, broken and sad, who had sung that song, and eventually died. Now, these two characters (Gelsomina and Zampano) are at the center of the film, but it's really Zampano's story in the end. He's left alone on a beach (the same beach that Gelsomina was found in the town and a similar beach to where the movie began) with nothing but the bitter feeling in his stomach that his loneliness and isolation at that time is entirely his own fault. He hasn't changed, but he has come to a realization (I've read it as "ripened", which I think is a good way to describe it). I'm not sure I would go so far as to call it a redemption, but it's certainly redemptive. He doesn't do anything to make up for his failings as a man responsible for a simple woman, but he does begin to understand his failings that led to his empty life. Gelsomina provided joy and happiness wherever she went, but she was never accepted, especially by Zampano who could have learned the most from her. It's a sad moment of a man, broken through his own actions and his own inability to love.Performance is at the center of this film, and Giulietta Masina gets most of the attention. She's a mixture of Chaplin and Harpo Marx as Gelsomina, and she's rather captivating, portraying a woman of some limited intelligence who also seems to be relatively self-aware at the same time, implying, to me, that she was mostly sheltered and not stupid. However, Quinn as Zampano is the core of the story, and he plays kind of a monster. He's fully realized as a man, but he's definitely a bad man who can't see the things and people that could make him better right in front of him, preferring to pursue his base desires exclusive to everything else. This ends up making me feel like Gelsomina is an angelic figure, sent to redeem Zampano and only succeeds through her own death.I've read La Strada described as a fable, and I think it fits rather perfectly. It's a tragic story of a man called to be more than his animalistic instincts but refuses. He ultimately learns his moral lesson, but only at great cost.This movie is great, perhaps even could be called a masterpiece. It's tragically sad and affecting, pulling the audience in to the story of these two people with incredible skill.

A care-free girl (Giulietta Masina) is sold to a traveling entertainer (Anthony Quinn), consequently enduring physical and emotional pain along the way.This film is huge and "one of the most influential films ever made", according to the American Film Institute. It won the inaugural Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film in 1956, and it was placed fourth in the 1992 British Film Institute directors' list of cinema's top 10 films. At no time has it ever disappeared from the IMDb Top 250, showing that general audiences love it, too.This is a great film, a fun film, with two characters really driving the story. Quinn and Masina tell the story with their faces, the laughs and snarls and everything else. Although the film was recorded in Italian, it could have survived as a silent film just as easily.

This film is a masterpiece because it tells a touching story: a showman bought an young and innocent woman for helping him in his travels through Italy where he makes his show.Zampanò is a very rude man (we don't know where he does come from, he never mentions his family), his life is to work hard and after that to have some drinks or spend a night with a whore. Gelsomina make all her efforts to learn how to play drums or trumpet, to care for him, to wait for him,etc.Gelsomina shows a lot of patience, underderstanding and and tenderness.Also she tries to speak with Zampanò, to undertand his story, but there are no answers.Once she is very tired of this life and escapes: in a town she looks at a tightrope walker, and we can see her happiness in her smile,she speaks a longtime with the Fool about the life and decides to go on with Zampanò.And then come the dramatic fight betweeen Zampanò and the Fool and Gelsomina has lost the taste of life.
This is great because of the extraordinary performances of Anthony and Giulietta Masina.The photography is very good: it seems that Fellini, Visconti, Vittorio de Sica had the change to work with the best photographers and cameramen of Italy.
La Strada is a very strong critic about the feminine condition: a young woman which has been sold, then has been beaten by his companion, humiliated (when she was waited while he was drinking or playing with women).
PS. I agree also with some reviewers who wrote that Giuletts Masina made own this film.

Developmentally delayed Gelsomina is called home to find out her sister Rosa has died and that Zampano the strongman has purchased her services to replace the sister and be an assistant to his traveling solo act. A brute of the first order he is soon abusing her both verbally and physically and while she vows to leave him she enjoys the attention she gets performing. When high wire artist Matto meets the two he mocks Gelsomina's looks and chides Zampano into rages. After Zampano is jailed briefly Gelsomina gets offers to go with other performers but is convinced by her own twisted logic she must look after Zampano.
