Things only get worse.La Strada is a heartbreakingly poignant film masterfully told by Federico Fellini with a grim simplicity of threadbare surreal and neorealist canvases of life on the road. Fellini presents us with the bleakest of settings (post war Italy) with three unattractive lost characters yet manages to extrapolate both humor and beauty from this tragic presentation of the human comedy. Giuelietta Massina's stunted Gelsomina blossoms from meek to full potential in a nicely measured way as she experiences life as an itinerant. There are moments in which she over mugs morphing into a Chaplin, Harpo hybrid but by far it remains a memorable and touching performance of lost innocence in the bleakest of circumstance. Anthony Quinn 's Zampano is dubbed but it is the physicality and hooded glances in addition to the all consuming violent nature displayed by Quinn that not only commands but threatens you to give him the same attention scene stealer Massina is getting. In the crucial role of The Fool Richard Baseheart brings both humor, tragedy and a bit of annoyanced into the scenario allowing Gelsomina a respite from the volatile Zampano and a chance to have a two sided conversation. Nino Rota's evocative score of melancholy and carnival joy ratchets up the emotional power to operatic many times in the bleakest of settings; all impressively sketched out by Fellini and cinematographer Otello Martelli's compositions of deft camera movement and placement. Rich in ambiguity and symbolism amid its barren environment, La Strada's deceptively simple narrative style remains timeless with its universal theme and trio of flawed drifters promoting supposition well after the lights have gone up. It is a moving film experience.

reviews.review_title: Anthony Quinn's brute is one of his greatest roles...
reviews.content: LA STRADA is a powerful experience, a wonderfully filmed masterpiece of its kind with tragic and comic overtones blended perfectly. Actually, it demonstrates in the end how much Zampano (ANTHONY QUINN as a strongman) and Gelsomina (GIULIETTE MASINA) really needed each other--something he would never admit to himself until he finds himself hearing her plaintive trumpet song and ends up alone and deserted on the beach in the final scene.Quinn has never sharply defined a brute as well as he does here--if possible, even more brutish than Stanley Kowalski ever was! As the "artichoke" girl with the mournful eyes, Masina is enormously effective in showing how sensitive her simple-minded character is beneath the harsh treatment and humiliation she must suffer in her search for affection.I would have preferred a soundtrack that used the haunting melody more effectively instead of random chords of music that crop up now and then. This would have added immeasurably to the brooding atmosphere of loneliness and despair in harsh surroundings.RICHARD BASEHART is outstanding as The Fool who cannot resist the temptation to tease and torment Zampano--to the point where he is brutalized by the brute in a final act of revenge. Basehart has never given a performance of this caliber before and is remarkable in all of his tender scenes with Masina.Summing up: A masterpiece of its kind, well worth experiencing.

With such simplicity one might wonder how Fellini pulled it off so marvelously. I saw this film after watching his masterpiece 8 1/2.. This one did not carry those complex scenes that need lots of interpretations, yet it had much depth in it and left a great deal of impact on me. Perhaps it was intended to have this simple plot because love that is the subject of this movie is simple and that is why it is so powerful.Zampano is the unmindful cruel man that cares for nothing but his pleasures.. he is a simple showman that travels from place to place to perform his acts. He starts taking Gelsomina, who is a poor simple minded young woman, with him in his rides after her mother sold her to him. Gelsomina is his contradiction.. an innocent pure soul that cares for others.. that wants to love and be loved.. that wants to give meaning to her life.She was miserable.. struggling with her new life when she learned from another showman, a character which seemed shallow from the outside and truly was deep from the inside, that everything was there for a reason and a purpose. Zampano, and so she thought, was the purpose of her being in life, and love was there.. but was it enough to change him..After a while she seemed crazier.. or maybe the insanity of people's acts were reflecting on her as she was purer and clearer than a mirror. She had a purpose and fought for it and there in every detail of this great film you will reflect on the simplicity and greatness of love.

reviews.review_title: But whatever happened to Sister Rosa?
reviews.content: "Rosa is dead." As deceased as Rosencranz, Guilderstern, and Jacob Marley put together. Why should we care? Maybe because it's the first line of this otherwise perfect movie, and Rosa is only alluded to a couple more times in its remaining 108 minutes. We never learn how, why, or where Rosa met her fate; the main mystery behind the story of LA STRADA only deepens. Since Rosa's sister Gelsomina has four much younger sisters left at home when she fades from view, it's possible to surmise that Zampano the Strongman had paid another 40,000 lira and already had run through them in sequence by the time he learns Gelsomina's destiny from the laundry lady. Perhaps that's why he seems so sad later on the beach. Possibly Gelsomina was "the best of the bunch," and now he realizes that the cupboard will be bare forevermore. As the Fool's bittersweet theme echos away, one can't help wondering if Fellini's wife (who plays Gelsomina) had sisters, which would have allowed Fellini to tell Rosa's story in a prequel to LA STRADA. If it hasn't been done already, when the character copyright holders give it the green light, maybe they can cast Jonah Hill as the young Zampano. If Jonah cannot speak fluent Italian, no big deal. There are probably more Italians in America than in Italy (which gets all its Olympic baseball players from here), and they speak English, so no one will have to read subtitles in order to understand the prequel about Rosa!

Do you remember that scene in La Nuit Americaine where the Italian diva is complaining about having to learn her lines? She says that when she works for Fellini all she has to say is rhubarb, rhubarb, rhubarb and then she can overdub the correct lines later. I was reminded of this when watching La Strada. I think, for technical reasons, in the early days of Italian cinema all films were shot silent and then overdubbed. This later became standard practice even when it was technically possible to record sound simultaneously. The Italian public seemed to accept it and probably the majority of the films they saw were dubbed American productions anyway. It also meant that Italian directors could increase their box office potential by importing British or American stars without their having to go to the trouble of learning an Italian script. This brings me back to Anthony Quinn and Richard Basehart in La Strada. I was trying to work out whether they were speaking their lines in English or whether they were just saying rhubarb rhubarb rhubarb. At least the voice given to Anthony Quinn sounded reasonable. Poor Richard Basehart was given a squeaky Italian voice. Still, they got no worse treatment than the Italian actors in the film whose lip movements bore no relationship to the soundtrack. Still, its a sign of what a wonderful film this is that I really enjoyed it despite these technical difficulties. Quinn made the most of a very unsympathetic role but Basehart was excellent even with his squeaky voice. The revelation for me was Giulieta Masina who was Chaplinesque in the role of Gelsomina

reviews.review_title: Restorations look fantastic, however the audio is poor
reviews.content: Others have said much regarding the talents of its director on this platform. My comment will be on the restoration. Visually the 4k scan looks fantastic - beautifully sharp with deep blacks and nice contrast. The audio track however is disappointing. As a projectionist who has run many older "academy ratio" films with mono soundtracks, I have found these particularly good. Nice rich sound with quantities in the lower spectrum that were pleasing and dialogue that was clear and pleasing to the ear. Not so with many European classic restorations. It seems that the visual elements are given a lot of attention but the audio is an afterthought. It was recorded using Westrex sound which Hollywood used but displays a harsh, distorted quality with a lack of bass. This could be better. No excuse being an "old movie". Maybe from the early 1930's but not in the 1950's by which time many advancements had been achieved in the area of audio in cinema.

reviews.review_title: One of the best films ever made: La Strada
reviews.content: La Strada (1954) is one of the best films ever made in my opinion. Anthony Quinn stars as a traveling strong man who buys a young girl Gelsomina to help him out in his traveling business and to be a servant. Quinn's character Zampano is a mean uncaring brute who's a very inconsiderate man. The young girl tries to do her best to get along with her new life until a fellow traveler/performer comes along and changes the duo's lives forever.Anthony Quinn was phenomenal in this movie, his finest hour as an actor. But Giulietta Masina as Gelsomina steals the movie. You can't help but fall in love with the clownish imp. What I enjoyed about this film was the passion and drama the brute and the girl's relationship with each other and how hard and cruel life is on the road. Trying to explain this film to you is really hard. Watch this film and experience this brilliance of Fellini's film-making.Highly recommended.

Federico Fellini is best known for the wild, bizarre, carnival images of his later film such as La Dolce Vita, 8 1/2, and Juliet of the Spirits. However, the change from neorealism to fantasy was not sudden but rather gradual as you can see in his early films, especially I vitelloni and La Strada.The setup here is one of the most simplistic stories in cinema history: a young woman is taken away from her poor family to replace her dead sister that used to work with a traveling strongman. The man, Zampano (Anthony Quinn), is a beast, quite literally as we see the way he treats the young, innocent Gelsomina (Giulietta Masina). She appears to perhaps be partially mentally-challenged, but she has the sweetness and simplicity of a child. Yet, for reasons not known to us, Zampano decides to mistreat her and use her as his slave rather than as his assistant. This does go a little overboard, until Gelsomina begins to fall for a trapeze artist, nicknamed "The Fool" (Richard Baseheart), who has the same innocent appearance but also has an obnoxious streak in him bound to get him in trouble.Despite all these somewhat rude, obnoxious or unruly characters, Fellini is able to make them human, mostly thanks to the performance of Masina, who is very Chaplinesque in her facial expressions and body language. The whole moral of the story is one that Fellini seems to enjoy telling repeatedly: not realizing how important something is until it is gone. The final shot reflects this so perfectly, it practically makes up for any shortcomings the film has prior to that. The film also has a great mixture of the raw emotion of these scenes combined with the fantasy feeling of the scenes with the circus and other carnival performers. Fellini walks a fine line between the real and the illusive, and the result is simply told but emotionally powerful.

La Strada isn't quite as understated as Fellini's earlier films, nor is it nearly as self-indulgent as his later films. La Strada is right in the middle, and utterly flawless. Masina is as captivating and charming as ever. Even more so. Her nuanced and measured performance is perfect. Anthony Quinn is simply amazing. His sheer presence is tremendous. His movement, his voice, his face . . . I've never seen him better. On all counts, this is a masterpiece. Fellini's earlier films seemed to be climbing towards this peak, and everything after it seems little more than an echo of its greatness. I don't think I've ever seen a better film.

One of Italian master filmmaker Frederico Fellini's greatest motion pictures, La Strada chronicles the tragic relationship between an emotionally closed-off beast of a traveling strongman and the child-like woman he literally purchases to assist in his act.  Giulietta Masina (Fellini's wife) plays the wide-eyed Gelsomina with tremendous depth and emotion -- it is not the abuse she suffers at the hands of the brutal Zampano that endears her to us but rather the fact that she can be so mistreated and still possess the ability to love.  Besides Masina, Anthony Quinn is perfectly cast as Zampano as is Richard Basehart as the doomed trickster acrobat Il Matto.

Zampano. And Gelsomina. Masks. For any time, any society, any place. So, tale about innocence and cruelty. About symbols and travels. And appearances like trap, ladder and feelings. La strada is a lesson. An anatomy lesson. Long cut along few lives. And crumbs from different bread. Hope, love, search of world with eyes of a new kind of Charlot. May be a sad story. Or cruel image by Fellini. But La Strada is reflection of passing hours. Poverty and representation of strongman, the stars - key for other reality,shows as holes and fear - ordinary skill, the end- ash trace, are spots for a drawing lost on beach. A fairy tale. Romantic, lucid, bitter, current. So, very harsh.

reviews.review_title: What makes this film great is lost on me
reviews.content: La Strada is one of the few times that I feel as if an acclaimed "masterpiece" has flown right over my head. While the premise of a poor girl traveling with a performer and navigating through their complex relationship is certainly an interesting one, the conclusion to the story is everything but satisfying. I don't need a cookie cutter love story or a happy ending to appreciate a film, but the two main characters in La Strada experience no conclusion to their character arcs, with Zampano's arc being nonexistent until the very end. The film has been praised as an unfiltered illustration of the human condition, but I struggled to find anything substantial to take away from that illustration. It feels like I'm truly missing something here. La Strada is hailed as a classic so maybe you'll find a different appreciation for the film but I just don't see justification for the praise it receives. All that said, the first two acts are thoroughly enjoyable and interesting. The acting is great and it's a very unique film, but I the conclusion leaves much to be desired.

A KVIFF screen of Fellini's black and white classic LA STRADA.First I must refresh my memory to gather all the Fellini's I have watched so far. from 8 AND A HALF (1963, a 9/10), LA DOLCE VITA (1960, a 9/10) to AMARCORD (1973, a 8/10), so LA STRADA is the fourth one. The film has a direct exertion of pathos by coupling two disparate characters, an angelically miserable Gelsomina (Masina) and an uncivilized macho Zampanò (Quinn), which may not pander to the New Wave trend at that time, but time proves its longevity and flags the upcoming career flourish which would verify Fellini as one of the most creative and intelligent film auteur in an historical scope. LA STRADA has a starkly primitive settings for the always-on-the-wheel couple, the gypsyish, footloose lifestyle seems to be endless and bleak along with the melancholic tunes, Gelsomina's hapless experience could melt any steel heart and her wide-eyed subservience is too heart-rending to even blame her; Zampanò, on another level, is a far cry from an evil soul, merely is a man with rudimentary desires and an irascible temper. Giulietta Masina did an almost-perfect work to embody herself with all the ups-and-downs of a poor girl's misadventure both inwards and outwards, her Chaplin-esque clown mimicry and antics have a genuine comedic infusion to the views and by comparison, Quinn's chest chain- snapping stunt is over-used and outdated, but he has his own time, namely, the scenes of his final wail of grief are the salvation for him (a great solace for the audiences as well). Richard Basehart, his portrayal of "Il Matto" is queerly vivacious, a sincere contrast to the adversity he would meet in due course. The cameras work miracles too, for example, the night shots of tightrope-walking among crowds has its enchanting depth of focus. Although the world in LA STRADA is a period I could never experience, and it is a more straightforward tale compared with Fellini's other oeuvres, but through the film I could potently sense a clear-minded manifesting of some most precious humility virtues which would also affect people under whatever conditions, to use a tear-jerking story to give hope, which is a marvelous achievement!

I appreciate the craft, I really do... but... A wail of exposition leading into a series of unnecessarily repetitive sequences of extreme melodrama did not do it for me. Not until the beautifully executed, emotional finale rolls around; a moment that wouldn't be possible without all of the long-winded, unintentionally comical melodrama with the leads whom I don't care for. Not until the very final moments.

Everyone raves about what a great film this is, but I don't get it at all. A woman travels throughout Italy with a strong man. He yells at her & whips her. For some unknown reason, she falls in love with him. This is weird. Most reviews I have read say this film is great at portraying "The Human Condition." My condition is nothing like this movie. My life is not weird.A lot of stuff happens that I don't understand. When Zampato and Geslina are in the café with the redhead, Geslina gets weird expressions on her face. I'm not sure what she is supposed to be feeling.I have trouble understanding all "art" movies. I didn't get "Ordinary People" or "Zorba the Greek." At least this movie wasn't as weird as "Zorba the Greek."

reviews.review_title: A beautiful, heart touching Classic from Italian Master Federico Fellini about compassion and guilt and how it can destroy life.
reviews.content:
La Strada / The Road (1954) :
Brief Review -A beautiful, heart touching Classic from Italian Master Federico Fellini about compassion and guilt and how it can destroy life. Fellini's crafting of human drama and his craving for showing new proportions in this mainstream genre is unmatchable. I can say it loud and firmly that during 50s and 60s there was no other director to compete him for that. I don't intend to disrespect other master directors from Hollywood and Foreign Language cinema who were ruling critics list and award ceremonies then, but you know every director has some special space of his own and others just can't fit in there. Fellini was the only Boss in this disturbing human drama club. La Strada is fortunately quite a popular flick because of Oscar doll in its Kitty. Without that, i don't think many people would have known about its existence. Well, sometimes Oscars do right things (not always) and the recognition to such films is important so yes i would give credit to Oscars for that and that's even after the fact i never cared about Oscar's Decisions. So, La Strada is pretty much a mixture of human drama with ingredients like love, compassion, misdeeds, guilt and at last realisation of the same. A care-free girl is sold to a traveling entertainer, consequently enduring physical and emotional pain along the way. Giulietta Masina as Gelsomina has acted like she was never acting. While watching her cute expressions i was telling myself, isn't it what they Call Method Acting? Anthony Quinn on the other side, brings that brutal male size hero+villain so beautifully that you hate him but can't resist loving him at the same time. That scream he puts out in the last scene is incredible. Fellini's draft is a cinematic classic by all means, no complaints about anything. We know it and we realise it by the End even if you have to wait for a little while for that so, Don't Miss.RATING - 8/10*By - #samthebestest.

Here is a film that I hadn't seen for over half a century, but I just revisited it. It was as though those 52 years had never happened as I found myself remembering every scene, every facial expression, and every nuance. Fellini is a master film maker and this film is a masterpiece. One doesn't even need the sub-titles to understand the film. The acting and direction are so superb it could actually be a silent film and have no written explanations at all, although sound is really necessary for the drum sequence by Guillietta Massina. What a delight she is, and Anthony Quinn is superb. Here we have a black and white picture with no gimmicks; a film you'll remember always. I highly recommend it.

reviews.review_title: I found the film extremely compelling to watch.
reviews.content: La Strada is a film best enjoyed by those who are over 35. I found the film extremely compelling to watch. The movie had a very slow pace and has movie subtitles. Usually these two things work against a movie for me but I was surprised I did not mind the subtitles nor mind the slow pace. The movie could have been silent (keep the music) for me to enjoy. The slow pace enabled the total enrapture of emotion by the viewer. It is not a movie to watch with a lot of people. It is a movie best enjoyed alone. The musical background scoring was entrancing as well and combined with the deliberate slow pace for movie enjoyment. Anthony Quinn is truly a master actor in this film. No popcorn here. Only a glass of wine with this movie.

reviews.review_title: Simple Yet Profoud Way Towards Heart
reviews.content: "Let's hurry to love other people, they pass away so fast." (Jan Twardowski) After all these years and so many different opinions about this movie, one assumption seems to prevail: there has hardly been a more powerful Fellini than in LA STRADA. His later masterpieces, according to many reviews, echo the powerful themes of this one. In this 'road film' Fellini addresses the vast majority of viewers. In other words, he practically packs all precious and communicative aspects of his visions to this little wonderful film that beautifully combines simplicity with profoundity and may still be considered as 'la strada' - the road/way towards viewers' hearts. Indeed, his contribution of skillfully emotional direction is undeniably deserving a praise but, let us say it frankly, what would LA STRADA be today without Giulietta Masina, Fellini's wife who could truly embody all sorts of feelings before the camera.Here, Giulietta Masina, in her Oscar winning performance (another one was one year later for NIGHTS OF CABIRIA), displays all that may appear genuine, unique, absorbing, touching in human existence. In a Chapliniesque performance (mind you she does not have many lines and all is written in the face) she is both a perfect comedian and a perfect tragic because she is not particularly attached to her gender. She is a child and a childlike heart, a pure soul. She makes us laugh and cry at the same time. And what is quite extraordinary about her performance is the fact that she does not recall any of her other leading roles in Fellini movies. She is Gelsomina here with no single comparison, reference to acting style or whatever else referred to in other movies. I was not a viewer who kept to the chronology and saw NIGHTS OF CABIRIA before LA STRADA and though the movies carry some resemblance of human drama within the skeptical and even sarcastic society, one cannot simply compare them. These are two different characters created uniquely on the screen thanks to masterful skills of Ms Masina. She is unforgettable in all the scenes of the movie, she leads a viewer to intense emotional experience through her tears while leaving the monastery, through her smiles at one reclusive kid Oswaldo, through her fearful eyes at Fool's death, through her sorrow of resignation on the streets. One of the most brilliant performances ever! The male characters make for an even more astonishing conclusion of psychology blended with simple perceptions. They are depicted in terms of their relations to Gelsomina. Anthony Quinn portrays legendary Zampano - a typical 'macho,' embodiment of arrogance that may evoke from physical strength, a man with lungs of steel and heart of disguise. Two scenes practically depicts his character in the most memorable ways: firstly, it is the bar scene when woman equals with flesh, a flesh to be taken advantage of and secondly, it is his final drama when he shouts out what has, actually, been hidden within him: "I need no friends! I need no one!" Can he occur a little human to such a genuine character as Gelsomina? What more does she mean for him but a 'monkey' to be trained, a 'slave' at hand? As his contrast comes Fool played by wonderful Richard Basehart (people interested in Italian cinema of the time will probably link the actor to Valentina Cortese, yes, he was her husband for a decade). Fool is not so much a fool but a vibrant and enthusiastic character who lightens up Gelsomina's darkest thoughts. He comes as a cure, as the one who, in an unforgettable scene of consolation, shows her a simple stone, a stone that exists in this world for some purpose. He is a legendary, symbolic optimist, weak in the eyes of powers of the world but quite captivating inside. Fool is the character that still has much to say to our modern yet depressed society. Like Gelsomina, he sees the world in simple terms, he can smile at a leaf, he can make other people laugh, unlike Zampano, directing his tricks towards people's enjoyable moments not narcissistic shows. Can Gelsomina like such a man on her 'la strada' of life? Indeed! But Zampano has something else to say and something outrageous to do...Apart from the flawless performances of Giulietta Masina, Anthony Quinn and Richard Basehart, LA STRADA can boast of wonderful art direction by Otello Martelli and tremendously touching music score by Fellini's mainstay, Nino Rota. The song of Gelsomina that finally leads Zampano to a moment of reflection, to a stop in his egocentric life is something that remains in the ear for long.But I think that many viewers nowadays skip the major point of this wonderful movie. They usually view it as merely an important production in Fellini's career or a significant product in history of cinema. But they do not see that this is one of such films that can timelessly speak to generations, to our generation too. It has the power to open us towards seeing other people, caring for them before it is too late. That is why I decided to open my review with this quotation of a man who certainly does not have much to do with the movie itself but his words beautifully refer to the content of LA STRADA.Start to love other people...was it too late for Zampano? In the waves, she appears to speak clearly while in silence childlike heart makes its safe 'la strada' Play your song, Gelsomina, play it to the world though it pretends to be mute to tunes of heart! Play it out loud as long as there are individuals somewhere on earth who dare shed a tear at your story.

Italian filmmaker Federico Fellini's 1954 black and white film La Strada (The Road) is one of those films that is midway between his early Neo-Realism and his later Magical Realism, with touches of both aplenty. It made both him and its female lead, his wife Giulieta Masina, stars, won the 1954 Venice Film Festival's top award and the 1956 Best Foreign Picture Academy Award, yet there is something missing from it. It is a good film, arguably a very good or near-great film, but it is definitely not a great film. It lacks the intellectual and artistic depth that the couple's next famed collaboration, Nights Of Cabiria, three years later, would have. In a sense, those critics who have called it a simple fable are correct, but even the greatest of fables cannot compare with the greatest of novels, especially those modern masterpieces, for a novel takes an in-depth 360° spin around life, and within life, whereas fables and this film often rely too strongly on archetypes, schmaltz, and sentimentality. It is not a reworking of The Beauty And The Beast tale, either, for it's not really a love story, but a loveless story, in the sense of the human denial of love. Granted, it's a mark of Fellini's consummate filmic skill that one is so easily emotionally manipulated, to the point that most viewers even care about the wretched Zampano at the film's end. But, mastering puppetry is not the same as producing good art. If it was the old Lassie American TV shows from the 1950s and 1960s would be right alongside The Odyssey and Guernica in the pantheon of great human artworks. Yet, Fellini is so great a filmmaker that even where his art is not top notch it can inspire admiration for its excellence. The story the film tells, penned by Fellini and his long time collaborator Tullio Pinelli, is first rate, even as it comes awfully close to syrupy, while the black and white cinematography by Otelo Martelli is solid. La Strada is not a visual feast for the eyes, and some mat shots as the pair drive around in their wagon date the film, even as they are better than the techniques that filmmakers like Alfred Hitchcock were using in America. But, the film is renowned most for the film score by Nino Rota, and the theme for Gelsomina that, even millions who've never heard of, much less seen, La Strada, will know from just a few bars. Yet, it does not hold up as well as other, later Fellini films, to a modern eye. It does have more in common with 1940s Hollywood films than many critics would like to admit, especially in the screenplay and scoring aspects that link it back to the social realism of 1930s American studio films- those starring a James Cagney or John Garfield.Still, given it's Fellini, it's much better than many other films ever made, for there are those moments one can only get in a Fellini film, just like Ingmar Bergman can only give you psychosexual angst at such a high and poetic level. With Fellini, it's those absurd moments that just stay within realistic bounds, like Gelsomina seeing a horse loudly clomping down a city street while alone and waiting for Zamapano to come back after a night with a whore, or seeing three country musicians marching by after she runs away from Zampano and is fascinated by an anthill, or her evocative theme song, first played on The Fool's mini-violin, or the oddly poetic and comic poof of a cloud that explodes from The Fool's inexplicably fiery car after Zampano pushes it off the road, into a ravine, after he kills the man. These are the touches that, even when a great artist is not in top form, separate that artist from all the many pretenders. Fellini was no pretender- he was the real thing, and La Strada is a very good film. But it was an even better augur.

reviews.review_title: I like Nights of Cabiria more
reviews.content: This early Fellini just did not affect me like Nights of Cabiria did, leaving me a little cold and unsatisfied. It has many of the same motifs: The same bleak post-war environment and poverty; predatory men abusing women, treating them as pets and playthings; musical processions; religious longing. Perhaps it was too predictable in it's plot, especially as I'd watched the Scorsese intro clip which gave away all the major story beats; perhaps I wasn't too impressed with Anthony Quinn, though he certainly has the looming brutishness to carry the part.I think though the major reason is that Giulietta Masina feels shackled here: As an actress as subservient to Quinn's brooding loutishness as her character is, and barely given any speaking lines. I wanted more of her, as we were treated to in Cabiria, where her expressive face and personality fills the screen. The argument that the film is about the Zampano character's transformation in the ending scene falls utterly flat to me, and I almost feel like Cabiria was a 'make up' project for Giulietta being so secondary to Quinn in La Strada. The Italian studio dubbing I also found somewhat distracting.But another reason is that La Strada does not feel as complex and layered as Nights of Cabiria. For example, the depth of despair, longing, and satire, shown in the church procession scene in Nights is just not present in this earlier film. However, I didn't get to re-watching with the commentary turned on, nor to the documentary on the 2nd Criterion disc. No doubt those will increase my appreciation.

This is one of the most beautiful, powerful films I've ever seen. I used to have it on video, and watched it several times, but it's been about six years since I watched it. I must say, it moved me perhaps more this time than ever before. The performances, the cinematography... as my friend said, "There is so much life in Fellini's movies" and it's true. The film seems so loaded with meaning and symbolism, and the fascination with the circus, as is so omnipresent in fellini's stories. The music is poignant, simple and succinct. Everything seems in the film for a reason. Nothing is wasted. Not a single scene. *SPOILERS*And to see Zampano break down in the last part, finally realizing his own humanity and awareness of other human lives other than his own is painful to watch, because you realize that it is too late. He has sacrificed two lives to come to the harsh realization that it is possible to love. There is a compassion, humanity and universality behind this tale that extends beyond time and space.

Gelsomina so sweet, so naïve. I am trying to follow this in Italian, and the English subtitles help. Anthony Quinn so brutish, so believably a lout with a heart of coal -- until later on when he helps Gelsomina -- and even later when he is utterly drenched with his own guilt and knows that The Fool and Gelsomina are gone. Their messages have seemingly been lost on him, but perhaps now is truly sorry for his horrible treatment of them.Did The Fool have a premature heart condition? I was hoping he was really alive, and would return to get Zampano back for trying to off-him. Did The Fool really care for Zampano? Why did The Fool spend so much time teasing Zampano? Gelsomina decided early on that Zampano was an outrageous bad guy, but later she seemed to have grown some sort of dependency and even "love" for him. Was she jealous of his one-night-stands with the local "donne delle sere" (ladies of the evening...). The Italian should be close to being correct.I loved Gelsomina's clown/mime face makeup. She was great at the dancing and trumpet playing. She always wanted to sing and dance professionally, so here she had to put up with stupid "the great" Zampano in order to achieve her ambition. Early on, Zampano beat her with a switch, and did other bad things to her physically, later. She was smart to leave him. I had hoped she would go off with The Fool, riding off with him into the sunset. I thought at first look that The Fool was really cute and very, very nice, compared to Zampano.The Fool was clean-cut, and seemed more the sort of man that Gelsomina deserved. I thought Basehart was really cute in this movie, seeing him for the first time as a flesh-and-blood good-looking man, but I remember he had not-so-romantic roles in other movies. Basehart was very darling to look at in "La Strada", especially with his curly hair. I thought it was very smart of Director Federico Fellini to have Basehart lie back on that bench with his feet in the air, delivering his lines. Zampano could never have pulled off a lighthearted scene like this. Il Matto/The Fool had a very playful, daring and smiling personality.I still love song and dance movies best. You know that. Gelsomina danced, and so did The Fool, in a way. When on his high wire, The Fool was a great artist and athlete -- and he was dancing with the forces of nature. He was very popular with the crowds below, and they loved him. In contrast, Zampano's "performance" was merely to break metal chains surrounding his chest. Zampano had a rough caveman-type personality, while The Fool danced through life in a happy, carefree manner.Looks like Gelsomina was way smarter than The Great Zampano. So was The Fool. Zampano, in the end, was alone, friendless and utterly saddened. His life was over. He was a ruined man.10/10

reviews.review_title: A magnificent film with a particularly great performance by Anthony Quinn
reviews.content: La Strada is a 1954 film directed by Federico Fellini and starring Anthony Quinn, Giulietta Masina and Richard Basehart.La Strada is a beautiful film, arguably the best rendition of this type of story I have ever seen. It's two main characters are played by Giulietta Masina and Anthony Quinn, both perfect for the roles they got; Masina, who I only found out recently was Fellini's wife, with her fragile look is great as Gelsomina however I would argue it's Quinn's performance as the bruttish Zampano the most unforgettable of the two, I haven't seen him in any other film besides Lawrence Of Arabia but I can deduce from both of these masterpieces that he must be one of the great actors of cinema.The black and white cinematography is gorgeous and some of the visuals in this film are simply unforgettable, the best example probably being Il Matto eating spaghetti on the wire.The wonderfull score is by Nino Rota who also starred in another of Fellini's great films, I Vitelloni, and it beautifully complements the film.Despite all of this I still can't quite say I like it as much as I Vitelloni, the film from this director I saw previously, who hits me on a very personal level, but nontheless this was an incredible watch and it only hightened my expectations for the next Fellini film I'll watch, La Dolce Vita.9.6/10.

La Strada is a masterpiece. Fortunately, it has been acknowledge as one for more than 50 years and it has been widely discussed and analyzed for some of the most talented film scholars. There is also a variety of very goods review here in IMDb. There is nothing insightful I can add to those reviews. I would only recommend you to watch this movie. And watch it not only once, but at least twice. And watch it again. Part of its beauty is that Fellini doesn't impose a message on it; instead you are free to draw your own conclusions and get you very own interpretation of this apparently simple story. And those conclusions and interpretations may change or expand every time you watch it. Also, in a first view you may be totally absorbed by the great performances of Mighty Quinn and genius Giuletta Masina. But in a second view you can pay a little more attention to our third player: Richard Basehart as Il Matto. Mr. Basehart was a great actor and he was a master in conveying a complex character with very subtle gestures. Underneath the joyous and carefree façade of Il Mato lies a painful loneliness. Just watch for the scene where Gelsomina is looking attentively at a pebble and Mr. Basehart is looking at her with a face showing a world of sadness. The shot last only a few seconds, but it's incredibly touching. And the movie is full of this kind of beautiful, meaningful vignettes. This movie made me fall in love with three things: 1950's movies, Fellini's films and Richard Basehart. Enjoy!

The amazing part of this film were the performances by players Giulietta Masina, Anthony Quinn, and Richard Basehart. Each were fantastic in their emotional performances, even the young Masina. Moments in the film hark back to the times of silent film with wide eyes telling more than the language alone.However, the story line is too confused. Masina shifts from each emotion as soon as she has it. While this shows great acting ability, it became tiresome. There is also very little that actually happens in the film. The introduction and resolution of "the fool" are pretty much all there is. I wish that these actors and actresses had a better script to work with.

reviews.review_title: The score in his movies is simply amazing
reviews.content: This is my second Fellini movie ( first was 8 1/2) and it was fun movie but I would say different from 8 1/2. This one feels little less existential but has a lot of elements of it. I loved the characterization of the main protagonists and overall message of the movie. Fellini movies are really something else.

One of Fellini's best, La Strada is the story of a road that is traveled down by a (an odd) couple of circus like characters. One, a relic from the past who is the Beast-man of the movie. The other, the childlike, and Chaplin like woman who represents the innocence of post World War 2 Italy. Together, they travel down the Road, searching for the end. On the way, we see the two try to become a couple. Quinn is fantastic as his character attempts to hold onto what shred of meaning he has in his life. The second wife he takes attempts to show love for him but he doesn't allow it.The struggle of love between the couple is unique as it is also ordinary in everyday life. Two souls intersecting down the road of life. On the road, the Fool is killed, and at the very end, Zampanò leaves his only true love behind. The winner of the first academy award for best foreign film, La Strada is important to all Felini fans.
A stark exploration of the choices we make. A great musical track compliments a moving story and shows the sad end for someone who chooses selfishness over compassion. A re- watchable.

One of the most melancholic films I've seen. La Strada shows how great of a director and writer Fellini really is. With the help of the acting talents of Anthony Quinn Fellini established a simple neorealistic storyline and used the poverty, the oppression, and the desperation issues as main obstacles for the characters in order to reveal the true hidden human side. (Hearing gelsomina's melody for the last time was heartbreaking)

Movies that one can't identify with in some way are not interesting to me. This movie shows a man at one end of a spectrum (the brute) just as Dark Eyes shows man at the opposite end of the same spectrum (the vacuous playboy). Just as we see elements of each in ourselves we also come to see that our value as men lies in keeping both ends of the spectrum at bay. Both movies are simply unforgettable.It must have been jolting for Mastroiano (sp?) as the playboy as well as Quinn (the brute) to portray characters that are not so much fictional as they are part of the hidden psyche or all men, some characteristic that exists deep down in all men and occasionally comes close to the surface and must be subdued as monstrous and terrifying to others.

It is set in post-war Italy and follows the lives of a street performer and his female assistant.Gelsomina (Giulietta Masina, Fellini's wife) is a young woman described by her mother as "strange." She is naïve, and some would describe her as intellectually limited, but with an ability to accept and enjoy life in the moment. She learns her sister, Rosa, has died; she was an assistant to the traveling street performer, Zampanò (Anthony Quinn). Gelsomina's mother wants her to take Rosa's place as Zampanò has paid her 10,000 Lire for her.Zampanò turns out to be a large, quite brutal unfeeling man, who nonetheless trains Gelsomina to learn how to be a good assistant. She clowns well, especially with children, dances, and learns to drum and play the trumpet to support Zampanò's acts of strength. There is a distinct Charlie Chaplin naïve wisdom in her character. At one point, Zampanò and Gelsomina join a larger circus that includes Il Matto "The Fool" (Richard Basehart). The Fool is a high-wire performer who begins to mock Zampanò during the latter's performance. This results in a fight that lands both of them in jail, and both are dismissed from the circus. Martin Scorsese describes The Fool as a Robin Williams kind of character who always ends up pushing just beyond the edge.Sometime later, Zampanò and Gelsomina stay at a convent, and Gelsomina tries to bring their relationship to a head. She is emotionally attached to Zampanò, though it could hardly be described as love. She offers to marry him, but he is dismissive. Soon after leaving the convent, they encounter The Fool on the road repairing a tire on his car. Again The Fool mocks Zampanò, and they end up in a fight. Zampanò only strikes him a couple of times, but The Fool dies as a result. Zampanò tries to make the scene look like an auto accident, and they leave. However, the incident breaks Gelsomina's spirit, and she is no longer able to perform. Finally, one day, when she is asleep, Zampanò leaves her with some clothes, some money, and her trumpet and leaves.Four or five years later, Zampanò is part of a circus again, and in a town hears the song that Gelsomina used to play on the trumpet. The woman who was singing said her father had found a girl who did not speak but played that song. She had died several years before. Learning of this drives Zampanò to deep despair as he reflects on what he has lost.This film got a mixed reaction in Italy when first released but won the first Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film. It is said to include many themes that were important to Fellini. It is now regarded as a classic.

This movie came across as simple to view which is its strength. The story is down to earth and easy to track and another dynamic takes place that I so enjoy in certain movies. We get to capture for all time the streets, cities, background of these on-location shoots for all time. I like seeing how people dressed, what they ate, how they acted etc. and this film has plenty of that too. I have always enjoyed Anthony Quinn and this movie is no exception. The concept his character acts out is one of regret but not until he pushes what he can get a way with to the limit in this film as his character portrays. The ending is satisfying and one is allowed another dynamic that I look for in movies i.e. to ponder what happened after the film ended. Nicely done. Stay with this as in don't be in a hurry and you won't be disappointed for doing so. Why? Because .....

Drawing on the great traditions of  both silent and sound movies, Federico Fellini creates in La Strada a magical, poetic masterpiece,  which can  be enjoyed and interpreted on many levels. At its simplest, it is a moving story of unrequited love between two lonely people - Giulietta Masina's sweet, innocent Gelsomina and Anthony Quinn's brutish Zampano, a circus strongman, to whom she is sold to become his assistant. But Fellini adds to this basic, seemingly realistic, story many surreal and symbolic touches, so that the movie is not just about yearning, loss and rejection in human relationships, but about the search for meaning in an increasingly meaningless world, and ultimately perhaps about our loss of God and/or his rejection of us. Quinn's performance is one of his very best; Zampano's treatment of Gelsomina is loathsome, ranging from physical abuse to sheer thoughtlessness, but Quinn portrays him as no monster, just a flawed man. Masina is enchanting, whether she is mugging and prancing a la Harpo Marx in her job as Zampano's sidekick, or expressing her pride and devotion to him in those moments when he treats her as a companion rather than as a thing. Perhaps more complex and enigmatic than either of the principal characters is "Il Matto" (The Fool), a tightrope walker, played by Richard Basehart. Though on a superficial level, he is lighthearted, intelligent and versatile in contrast to Zampano's sourness, ignorance and reliance on a single trick, and although he befriends and supports Gelsomina, his mischievousness and intervention have a malicious edge, and eventually he is the agent of tragedy. Fellini emphasises the marginality - and economic poverty - of his characters by setting much of the movie in the wastelands at the edge of town, in roadside campsites, or on the beach between land and sea. But these empty, often ugly, prospects may also express the literally God-forsaken nature of much modern life. Nevertheless, there are contrasting scenes, depicting a richer side of life, such as the wedding scene, Il Matto's tightrope walk over the town square, and the religious procession that proceeds it. All aspects of the film are enhanced by Nino Rota's expressive score, containing orchestrations and themes used in other Fellini movies, which help create correspondences between these different films.La Strada has no happy ending, and indeed it could be regarded as a deeply pessimistic and even despairing work; but sentimentalists might prefer to suppose that Zampano has not reached the end of the road as he lies on the beach at the film's close, but will find redemption and rejoin life's circus.

Fellini was ahead of his time by about 50 years. La Strada is a shining example of how he was able to coalesce the tumultuous times of Italy with art that is not just beautiful but gut-wrenchingly real. The performances here are of course Oscar caliber, but not just that - they resonate with the full human experience, decades later. Belllisimo.

reviews.review_title: no wonder that Scorseze like this movie!I think that john Cassevetis like it also.
reviews.content: The matter why I'm saying that,because I watch Scorseze introducing LA STRADA.If u know SCorseze,and his movies,u ll find that it is been taken from streets ,from facts,from realistic life.As for fellini,he gives u the inspiration of the cruel life,and mean streets,bu his own way.I mean,he play the 2nd plan game.So he'll propose the mean guy(Anthony Queen)and in the same time gives u the humanity part of him.I mean ,this film has a lot to do with the method acting,between the actor studio guy,and the comedia del arte girl.I think both deserves the respect for their outstanding play.I mean,the girl keeps u in the circus ambiance,and Queen keeps u in the none easy way of life and the fight for living.Please,whatever was ur genre of movies,do not waste it,it is between our hands now,who knows,maybe u ll never find it after.

I won't take the time to rehash the story/plot as many others have already addressed so here. La Strada, like many Fellini films offers us many interesting and surreal visuals, which I think here are an essential element of the story itself. The visuals combined with the distinct and beautiful Rota score and wonderful cinematography truly creates a one of a kind world La Strada inhabits. The front facing story is simple but within the context of all the elements does raise larger questions and issues in the viewers mind. Masina, Quinn, and Basehart performances are all solid and generous. La Strada is most assuredly worth checking out.

I fell in love the moment Richard Basehart's il Matto (the Fool) appeared on the screen. I consider it one of the finest films ever made, if not _the_ finest. Basehart, Giuletta Masina (an excellent mix of fragility and wonder in the starring role of Gelsomina) and Anthony Quinn (very believable as an internally tormented, domineering strongman) are all flawlessly cast. I'd recommend this as an introduction to Fellini, for those who've never seen any of his films. It's the crowning achievement of his earlier, more realistic work, with a pinch of the fantastic. Il Matto is my favourite character in any medium.

This is a movie which art and a powerful story come together, because now I understand that an artistic movie without a powerful story or a powerful story without art does not save anything. This is from Fellini's first years, so there is a solid story, but also a work of art like I Vitelloni, but La Strada is one of my favorite Fellini films, from the early years of him, the best. And the film has a great final. Zampano is a very macho man and hurts people. When he gets angry because of any reason, but mostly they are not reasonable, he becomes a monster. It does not matter a man or a woman, he just attacks. Gelsomnia is a sweet and credulous girl, a 'Pollyanna'. Even if Zampano insults her, an inevitable fact, she does not do anything, instead she likes him. This might be interpreted as women mostly like tough guys, macho men or as she is too pure. May be, she has not another option. However, she likes a monster. She does whatever Zampano wants, a typical situation in the relationships of macho men and the women around them. And so on. La Strada is a real character movie, it says many things about men and women relationships and also love that is not a common thing in cinema. By the way, there is a little surprise in the movie which is about waking up. And the scene I will never forget. Zampano buys a cone of ice cream with lemon. He eats the whole ice cream with almost one bite. May be the coins in his pocket are only money that he has. However, he finishes it in a minute, without enjoying. He does not value it as he does not to the girl who likes him.

This is probably one of the best movies i have seen till date. The characters are real. The message is black. The best thing i liked about the movie is that circus is not romanticized meaning I got bored in the circus scenes as i get bored during the circus. This is Fellini's comprehensible cinema. You watch it and the impact is direct. It doest hit after 3 days in your sleep when all of a sudden some character from the movie pops up and plays around. I actually went to an Italian brothel in my dream after watching 'Roma'. Camel haunted me for days after Satyricon. I found this the best in the trilogy and otherwise also. Ill Bidone is also very good but solitude comes out gory in this one. The last beach scene reminds me of Ill Bidone but the helplessness of Zampano comes out so well. The whole chain breaking act of the zampano is just brilliant. It is so many times in the movie and every time I like it because it reminds me of all the roadside shows i have seen. Giulietta Masina is very good. She brings out the compassion even for the evil very well. Anthony Quinn rules the screen. Richrd Basehart-'The Fool' is also very convincing. A great movie. Great message.

reviews.review_title: One if my truly favorite films
reviews.content:
This is what good storytelling is about.
Among my top 10 I'd take to desert isle.
Fellini made a trio of films, this one, Il Bidone and Nights of Cabiria. I saw La Strada in big theater in Los Angeles in 1986 i think.
American audiences are used to certain endings. Fellini didn't play that.

La Strada brings two souls together to tell a story that ultimately displays humanity's finer aspects. The title gives a clue to the meaning of Fellini's masterpiece: The Way. The brute, Zampano, buys the urchin-like Gelsomina to be his traveling companion in his one-man carnival act. He is physically and emotionally cruel to her. Her longing to love and be loved, and her child-like, yet acute perception of life, and desire to live it, despite hardships, makes her the perfect complement to the selfish and despicable Zampano. Their unification affects each other. However, although Zampano's harshness adversely effects Gelsomina's life, it is her influence that will eventually, and more significantly, change him. This may sound like the familiar Beauty and the Beast fairy tale, but it is more than a love story. It is about love, but it isn't until the very end of the film that we realize it. More than love, it is about a man who gains insight and awareness because of love. It is his finale transformation that demonstrates both the frailty and vitality of the human condition. It overpoweringly suggests that the individual, no matter how depraved, is able to spiritually evolve.Every frame and scene in this masterpiece has purpose and meaning.

La Strada is such a simple story. The black and white cinematography is very stark and creates an almost otherworldly environment. Felini's wife plays Gelsomina, a naive girl from a poor family who is taken in by Zampano (the strong man). In what almost feels like a fairy tale, Felini creates a story of three disparate characters who lives intersect and result in tragedy. Incredibly touching and sad. It's no wonder it's considered Fellini's masterpiece.

'La Strada' is considered by many critics to be the first film made by Fellini which can be given the tag Felliniesque. His earlier work as a screenwriter as well as his previously directed films had a very palpable sense of neo-realism enriching them. This was the first film where Fellini started to break off from some of the norms of Italian neo-realism and make a gradual transition to a more poetic and surreal visual language. This directorial decision also made a number of Italian critics of the time negatively remark upon the film as well as Fellini for his 'betrayal' of neo-realism.Having said all that, I still think that 'La Strada' borrows the basic societal background from neo-realist films. The film opens with Gelsomina's family. We get to know about their sorry plight from a financial standpoint. The matriarch has to sell off Gelsomina to Zampano just to get some money so that the others in the family could be fed. This element of abject poverty in post WW2 Italy forcing ordinary people to compromise is something that was an integral part of Italian neo-realist cinema. But in the previous neo-realist films, this economic insufficiency served as the main driver of the plot, whereas in 'La Strada', Fellini uses this poverty as the backdrop, but the essential driver of the plot is the personal existential crisis suffered by the characters. The screenplay of the film written by Fellini, Tullio Pinelli and Ennio Flaiano is simple. The basic storyline is something which is very familiar. Two different characters get together and they hit the road and on the way they confront certain realities about themselves. But Fellini, through his direction adds a fantasy/fairy tale like element to the film that makes it unique. Gelsomina is a naive, gullible young woman who gets thrown into an unfamiliar world with a complete stranger. Zampano is the big, arrogant, rude, brute of a man who keeps treating Gelsomina in the worst ways possible which involves constant slapping and physical assaults. She keeps taking it because she loves the actual performing aspect of the work. She keeps wandering off akin to her natural wild ways. She then meets The Fool, another travelling artist. Although he is not the most perfect individual either, but even then he is the one who at least verbally communicates with Gelsomina and gives her hope and encouragement by telling her that everyone, including she has a purpose on this Earth. In a way the film can be viewed as a vehicle for the transition that takes place in Zampano's character. 'La Strada' in Italian translates to The Road. It is Zampano who travels on the road to achieving a conscience. He gradually comes to realise the wrongness of his ways and behaviour and repents. But he does so when it's too late. Although 'La Strada' doesn't have the visual flair and bravura to the extent that is present in the Fellini films from 'La Dolce Vita' onward, however even with the restrained camera work, there are still moments of typical Felliniesque surreal visuals like the sight of a single horse walking down the street, the three musicians appearing out of nowhere to cheer up Gelsomina, the shot of The Fool wearing angel wings sitting on a chair on the rope suspended in the air,etc. Nino Rota's music beautifully accentuates the moments of a change in tone. The camera movement is restrained, but still expressive. Fellini uses the beach in a thematically rich way which elevates the scenes staged there.For me the best performance in the film comes from Anthony Quinn. The character Zampano represents the cold, brooding individual who has decided to wear a thick armour of insensitivity. His character represents a cynical world view which juxtaposes the naive and gullible character of Gelsomina and also to some extent The Fool. Just like Jake LaMotta in 'Raging Bull', Zampano is a character that is easy to loathe due to his despicable demeanour. However Fellini gives Zampano the chance to start his journey at redemption through the heartbreaking last scene of the film where Quinn gives a masterclass of emoting and expressing so much without saying a single word.The only reason why, 'La Strada' doesn't get an 9 or 10 in my books is because of the way Fellini uses the character of Gelsomina. From a thematic standpoint her character makes sense. But the way in which she gets portrayed by Giulietta Masina is a little too corny. I can understand that the exaggerated mannerisms and Charlie Chaplin-esque antics goes with the fairy tale-esque feel of the storyline. She even looks adorable with the big eyes and it does break your heart when she is constantly abused by Zampano and forced to grow up. But I do think, the film could have worked slightly better with a little more understatement to her character mixed with the clown-like behaviour during the performance scenes.I don't think 'La Strada' is a perfect film, but it still has so many elements that could be admired. Fellini's command over the visual language is very apparent. This is the work of a master filmmaker who was still sharpening his skills.

reviews.review_title: La Strada is well-loved by Fellini diehards because of its simplistic filmmaking though it remains to be one of the director's lesser efforts.
reviews.content: La Strada or The Road as it is literally translated is the winner of the Oscar for Best Foreign Language Feature in 1954. Directed by the late Federico Fellini, a world cinema great whose body of work includes influential films such as 8½ (1963) and Amarcord (1973), La Strada is perhaps his most accessible feature. It is well-loved by Fellini diehards because of its simplistic filmmaking though it remains to be one of the director's lesser efforts. Often described as 'a magnificent ringmaster', the Italian filmmaker loves to re-imagine the circus in cinema. His characters are like clowns in an act; they are sometimes innocent, at other times mischievous. Fellini calls La Strada "the complete catalogue of my entire mythological world". While that is slightly exaggerating, there is no doubt that the film most resembles an intimate circus performance, an environment whose oddball characters feel at ease playing their roles as entertainers. Starring Anthony Quinn as Zampano The Strongman, Giulietta Masina as Gelsomina, and Richard Basehart as The Fool, La Strada is a comically tragic film that focuses on the plight of the waif and retarded Gelsomina. She is sold to the grumpy and short-fused Zampano by her poor mother, riding on an old, rusty bike trailer as she follows him around Italy as his assistant in his shows. They meet The Fool in their journey, a man who loves to flirt with danger either walking the tightrope or agitating Zampano in a series of verbal and physical pranks. Fellini uses the distinctive, expressive face of Masina to marvelous effect whose gestures are a reminiscent of Chaplin. Although not very smart, Masina's character appears to have a cheerful persona. Unfortunately, she does not feel loved by Zampano (who likes Gelsomina but is incapable of expressing love), often cutting a lonely figure, and tries to seek solace in The Fool as well as through her role as a performer. As a result of Zampano's actions, La Strada becomes a wrenching tale of unfulfilled emotions and unredeemable regrets. Fellini's fourth feature is one of the first few films to move away from the Italian postwar neo-realism depicted in films such as The Bicycle Thieves (1948) and Umberto D (1952). Told in a mostly fabulist style, La Strada is accompanied by great music by the legendary Nino Rota (The Godfather), a frequent collaborator with Fellini. Not only does the film feature outstanding screen performances, it gives viewers significant insights to the flaws of the human character. La Strada is also the film that launched Fellini's international career whose future works often revisit similar themes. GRADE: B+ (8/10 or 3.5 stars)www.filmnomenon.blogspot.comAll rights reserved.

reviews.review_title: HORRIBLY DEPRESSING!!! Don't waste your time
reviews.content: I gave this 2 stars only for the performances, but this movie is awful. I LOVE most all old movies from the 1930s to the 50s, but this was the exception. From the first scene, it was depressing. I started to turn it off, but kept watching thinking it would get better. IT DOESN'T. At some point, you think they are perhaps trying to show that everyone has a purpose. If that was the point, you can get that elsewhere in a much more positive way. I thought at the very end that they might perhaps halfway save this with a different ending, which would have helped A LITTLE. BUT NOPE. I'd say it was a waste of time, but it was worse than that...an AWFUL way to spend your time. Wish I could have my two hours back! DEEEE-PRESSING big time.

I thought I was unfamiliar with Giulietta Masina, but after checking with IMDB, I find I have seen her earlier in Fellini's "Juliet of the Spirits." But I was not nearly as impressed with her in that as I was in this.  She is unforgettable in "La Strada".  I watched this for Quinn and Basehart, and they are both great.  But Giulietta Masina looks like the love child of Harpo Marx.  There are times, as one of your other readers indicated, when she does seem to drop the emotions too quickly.  But I think that is part of the charm of the character.  She is a rather simple girl from an impoverished time, and she has never had anyone love her completely. Consequently, she doesn't love herself fully; but she has enough dignity to know that she should.  And that others in her life should at least try to love.  It's quite an accomplishment.  And to be frank, I had almost given up on watching Fellini films because I've watched so many that just left me cold.  But this one makes me want to see more.

La Strada is among Fellini's best films. Later, some of his films became more obscure and arty. This simple story of two diametrically opposite characters brought together against the backdrop of post-war poverty stricken Italy is superbly told through stunning B&W cinematography, haunting music and exceptional performances by the lead actors, especially Anthony Quinn as Zampano. The man, a roadside performer, is incapable of any soft feelings, let alone love, for another human being. The girl, sold to him by her mother, hates his insensitive and brute nature, yet tries to adjust, till he commits a horrific act which scars her already fragile psyche, and a point of no return has reached between the two. The manner of his desertion of her is one of the most poignant moments of the film for the audience, his own repentance though too late comes many years later in the final scene.

There's a wealth of things to comment on but I'm sure most of them are already covered. So I'll mention the few that struck me most.One is the narrative perspective. Up until mid-third act, I thought this was Gelsomina's story. But then comes Zampano's abandonment. To be in keeping with the film to point, Fellini would have had her fall asleep and wake to find money in her hand and the trumpet by her side. Instead we see it from Zampano's perspective, and after he abandons her the story is firmly his.With this in mind, the movie shifts from a story about either Gelsomina or Zampano, and becomes a narrative tracing the path of loneliness. It attaches to and follows each character for a time until exhausting that soul, killing it, and moving on. Much like the nuns who move from convent to convent avoiding attachment to worldly things; Zampano avoids this too, and leaves a trail of spiritual debris in his wake.The film is nicely framed by three encounters on the beach, each representing the narrative shift -- Gelsomina; then Gelsomina and Zampano; and finally Zampano alone. Every pebble has a purpose. But if enough time (seawater) passes over the pebble it will be crushed, lose its identity and its meaning. In the end he is crying, clutching the pebble's waste.

reviews.review_title: Where are all the Gelsominas of this world?
reviews.content: Giulietta Masina's portrayal of Gelsomina is probably one of the few performances in movies that it wouldn't be an overstatement to call it the greatest performance of all times. Thus, Gelsomina is the greatest character ever walked on the silver screen - so carefree and joyful, yet so complex. No other actress could have to turn out such a layered character with such subtle nuances. Of course, Giulietta Masina's peculiar beauty helped a lot. Such a character can only be supported by an equally strong and morally complex character and that Anthony Quinn's Zampano is. Not a nasty or a bad man by default, but someone who knows what he is doing wrong, yet he can't get things going straight. He is capable of cruel things, but after he, although trying to find excuses, still feels regret, and blames himself.'La strada' (The Street) is exactly the kind of movie that only Federico Fellini is capable of making. While his contemporaries were known for (neo)realistic movies, the Fellini created magical realism and that 'La strada' is - a realistic voyage of traveling artists through the magic of creativity. The film is simple story, yet almost every frame hides something else underneath.

First of all,I love neo-realistic Italian cinema more than cinema of my own country(India) because they make movies on very realistic subjects without making audience fool by showing fake emotions and stories and above all their cinema is daring and reaches to very end of human emotions and left a very profound affect on us.I can easily relate and involve myself to these movies,no matter they are 50 years old.I felt same when i saw la strada,another Fellini's masterpiece.la strada is a highest and purest form of cinema making.neo-realistic and also full of adventure and emotions.Fellini's direction is flawless(as always) and also have great performances of Giulietta Masina as a very sweet and innocent girl she bring her emotions of fear,joy,innocence and madness very intelligibly.Anthony Quinn was great too as emotionless,careless traveling entertainer.La Strada is engaging and entertaining from beginning to end. Surely a masterpiece,one of the greatest cinema of history.i give this movie 10/10

In this film, Giulietta Masina is a better female comic than Lucille Ball, a more pathetic character than Charlie Chaplin's Poor Soul, and a more bemused individual than Stan Laurel. As Gelsomina Di Constanzo she is simply spectacular. Her eye movements and facial expressions lead the viewer to laughter one moment and pathos the next. In keeping with the classical tradition of comedy, she starts out with romantic idealism only to continually flop into morose realism as she tries to experience life on the road. She is forced to deal with a vindictive Zampano (Anthony Quinn)and a malicious Fool (Richard Basehart), armed only with the inexperience granted a poor girl sold by her mother. She wants to fit in, yet can she ever? This is all foreshadowed in the opening scene on the beach constructed much like Picasso's Expressionistic "Tragedy." The Left Elbow Index consider seven elements of film--acting, plot, production sets, dialogue, artistry, film continuity, and character development--on a scale of 10 for very good, 5 for average, and 1 for it needs help. Without question, Masina's acting is superb, which towers over a cast of excellent actors acting excellently. More of the same in other films would have been an special theatrical gift. The plot is also above average, most likely because it incorporates a good story, but also because it contains a never ending element of suspense. What indeed will happen to Gelsomina? The production sets are average. One can only do so much with the outdoors in post-war Italy. So with the artistry in the film, although the camera angles are helpful. Film continuity suffers from the confusing relation of action and scene in places, but the attentive viewer can work around this. The dialogue is above average, even the shouting scenes are not too disruptive. That of the haggling scene is good, and The Fool recalls Shakespeare. Character development is far above average with recognition occurring as Gelsomnia has one experience after another. She tries to fit in, and succeeds to one degree or another. The LEI average is 7.85, raised to an 8 (which equates to a 10 on the IMDb scale)based solely on the toothpick scene. This film is extraordinary for 1954, and one would think that it marked a beginning of good film making. There is a bushel of very good films since, but the trend is away from such excellence resulting in a trainload of much, much poorer movies. Unfortunately, it seems, all art is not evolutionary. I strongly recommend this film. It is mandatory to see the Italian version, for even with subtitles it is far superior to the dubbed English cuts.

The best of Fellini. It remains in the top echelon of movies. La Strada blends the elements of Chaplinesque (silent) movie style with a low key sound approach that exudes the best of both eras. The dialogue does not waste one word. Words are spoken when needed and increase our understanding of each character. The performances rank as the best in each of the actors and actresses careers. What may appear to be a simple movie or story on the surface only adds to it poignancy. The journey,"the road", each person is traveling brings them to a crossroad where their personalities, actions, and approach to life allows for no retreat. A movie sharing smiles, tears, and heart without pounding you over the head with them.

This drew mixed reactions in our house: some of us enjoyed the film and it's cinematography.  Others felt it was too slow to show it's plot.  Yes, it is slow.  But remember that you are watching the foolish Gelsomina grow wiser, while Zampanò, the strong man, is succumbing to a force stronger than his body: his conscience.  That kind of plot takes time to develop, unless you use more literal tactics.  (Personally, I liked the subtlety).  But, if you're one who doesn't enjoy a character driven plot, then sit back and drink in the scenery: a beautifully shot black and white film in post war Italy with some odd characters that could only be called "Fellini-esque".

reviews.review_title: don't be left on the road on your own
reviews.content: This is an unusual film and may not be to everyone's taste, but it is a great film. Guilietta Masina's performance as Gelsomina is much different in this film than her emotional and animated character, Cabiria. Here she plays her role almost like a mime or clown, expressing her emotion more through body language and facial expression. Not a type of acting I'm used to seeing, and it took me awhile to warm up to it. She plays a very gentle but devoted innocent. Anthony Quinn gives an award-worthy performance as a tough, violent strong man who buys Gelsomina from her destitute mother and treats her almost as a slave, even though she would do most anything to please and comes to love him. Basehart is also great playing the acrobatic clown who enjoys making fun of the strong man, and teaches Gelsomina about life. After some tragic events, though, in the end the Strong Man realizes something very important about his life.

I regularly praise this film to such high heavens that every time I watch it, I expect it to not be as good as I remember. And every time it's better.This is a film about love - not a romance, but an exploration of what it means to love and be loved. Set to an unforgettable soundtrack this subtle, quiet film manages to be both hilarious and heartbreaking while delivering its musings on humans and their feelings.Somehow, despite the tragedy within the story, I'm always left with a renewed sense of faith in humanity.

I'm sorry to hear of the passing of Anthony Quinn.  As I recall, the first time I saw him was when I was in grade school and thumbing through a book about old movies.  I came across an article about "La Strada," and I was instantly impressed (maybe a little scared) by his taut, darkling, weatherbeaten face.  Seeing his movies, I also became very impressed by his voracious vitality. 
Quinn may have won Oscars for "¡Viva Zapata!" and "Lust for Life" (the perfect choice to play renegade painter Paul Gauguin!), but to me, his best performance was in Fellini's "La Strada."  His dynamic embodiment of the brutish Zampanò is, to me, one of the all-time great appearances in film history.  I once saw him in person here in L.A.  I was buying a movie ticket and saw him standing off to one side while someone (a relative or an assistant) bought a ticket for him.  I was tempted to go up to him and say, "Ciao, Zampanò," but I thought it would be inappropriate.  I never got the chance again.  So, now that he's gone, I'll say it: Ciao, Zampanò.  Thanks for all the great memories.

Gelsomina is sold for a few coins to Zampano, a wrestler.  Between the two of them is "the fool" who is always disturbing Zampano. This subject matter personalities is in the film.  Zampano is a beast, the other is a stupid and the girl turns crazy.  Can Zampano survive alone? Very good movie with Richard Basehart and Anthony Quinn voices dubbed. Great performances by all.  Worth take a look.

Well my review will not add anything new but I will write another one any way! WHAT A FANTASTIC STORY!!! Sad but beautiful LA STRADA is one of Fellinis greatest movies (if not the best one). Gelsomina is a great, fun and charming character (what a amazing actress by the way, shes like Italian Charli Chaplin or Harpo Marx) and unlike people often mistake she is *NOT* retarded but a simple person unfamiliar with the evils of the world, but full of wonder and thinking with her hearth. I strongly recommend this movie to any fan of good cinema!Im just sad that they don't do movies like this any more... to bad!

reviews.review_title: search for happiness destined to fail
reviews.content: this the second Federico Fellini film that i see, after I Vitelloni which i liked quite a lot.
